"You can easily tell which is which though," says Slumblebore brightening. "The raisins have a sort of skin to them whereas the droppings are the same texture all the way through.

"Why do I tell you all this Arthur? I want you to know that for all my students I will always be there for them. I will always be there for you, when you need help the most. Always, Arthur, always. Metaphorically. Just like I was for Barry. Or was it Larry.
choice_1_text: "Did you say you have something important to tell me?" you ask Slumblebore
title: Wesley the Weasel

content:
You decide to go to the Defense Against Dark Magic class next. With Slumblebore warning of danger lurking in the dungeon, you want to be prepared.

Professor Madame Blavatsky's classroom is tucked away in an inconspicuous side passage and you almost miss it as you walk past. The inside is much more impressive though, with the floor and walls covered in inky black runes and pictograms, protecting the room against baleful influences.

The professor herself is sitting cross-legged on a little platform at the front of the classroom with her eyes closed while the children file in.

She is a short lady, wearing black robes and, because she is sitting with her legs crossed, looks a little like a large black frog. Her face is pale, almost white, and you can see networks of blue veins under the skin near her temples, like a river draining into a swamp.

As the last child sits down, she opens her eyes.

Her eyeballs gleam white, her irises a brilliant blue. 

"Welcome children, to Defence Against Dark Magic. The most important lesson you will learn today is..." Blavatsky's melodious, soothing voice pauses for a moment.

"...control over your own mind. Because it is only when you have full control over yourself that you can hope to resist the control that dark forces may wish to exercise upon you."

"And what is the path to self control?"

There is silence in the room. 

"It is self awareness. It is only by knowing yourself that you can control yourself."

You look over at Snako and raise your eyebrows. You were hoping for some powerful magic spells straight away, not this mystic rubbish.

"But..." continues Madame Blavatsky, "I sense a doubter in the room. You!" She turns her blue eyes on yours and fixes you in her gaze. 

"Have you already mastered yourself young man," she says to you. "Do you really know who you are?"

The blue eyes bore into you and you reply:
choice_1_text: Yes I know I'm Arthur Otley. I know what I'm thinking too, which is that I want to learn some real spells.
choice_2_text: "Well, I'm not sure. I know my name - it's Arthur Otley - but is that who I am or just what I others call me?"
title: Defense against Dark Magic

content:
Making sure that you have got all of your quills, ink bottles, quill sharpeners, spell books and sweets, you put your bag on your shoulder and leave the Great Hall to go back to the House Tower with Kensley.

Strangely enough you find you can remember the way back there easily - the path had seemed so long and winding on your first day. Perhaps it was something to do with eating the Hedgehog Egg from Percy the Picking Pigeon that has given you a homing instinct for the Tower.

When you arrive, experiencing the odd sensation of going _up_ the tower only to _emerge out_ from a hole in the ground, you go straight to your Hogger Hole, sit down on the bench outside your front door, and put your feet up with a happy sigh.

Refreshed you turn to Kensley who is sitting on a bench outside _her_ hole next to you and say:
choice_1_text: Let's go get some dinner, I'm absolutely famished.
choice_2_text: I'm not hungry today, I'm just going to get some rest so I am fresh for the morning. With that you retire to your cosy bedroom, snuggle under the duvet and quickly fall fast asleep.
title: Lessons finished for the day

content:
"I know I am called Arthur Otley," you say. "But am I defined by my name?"

"Excellent point Arthur! I can see by your question that you are already on the path to enlightenment. Because it is only when we realise that we _don't_ know everything that we can learn."

Madame Blavatsky smiles at you. "And because you are ready to learn I will now teach you your first spell."

"But first can anyone tell me," she says addressing the whole class now, "what is the most common cause of death for wizards and witches? Anyone?"

"Cave trolls?" suggests Daniel.

"Dragons?" proposes another child.

"Harpies? Banshees? Herpes?"

"No, no and no again." replies Professor Blavatsky. "I'm afraid that the one thing that is most likely to kill you more than anything else is: each other."

"Let me explain. Imagine it is night time, 3am in the morning. You hear a noise downstairs. Immediately you are on the alert. It could be burglars. Or more likely dark wizards on the attack. You creep downstairs, wand at the ready. You can hear them rummaging around in the kitchen. You leap out shouting the most deadly spells you can think of. Only to discover... it is your Uncle Brian who is visiting for the weekend and has come down in the night to help himself to a biscuit. Now he is paralysed on the kitchen floor, a look of horror on his face and the packet of biscuits grasped so tightly in his hand that no-one else will be eating them ever again."

"Yes I'm afraid to say that the most common cause of death is 'friendly fire', accidentally hitting your friends and family with dangerous or deadly spells. The sad fact is that you are all in far more danger from each other than from any evil sorcerer. Which is why the spell I am going to teach you to protect against dark magic is a sleeping spell. It is one I designed myself. The benefit of this spell is that it is completely reversible. To wake someone up, you just need to tickle them under their armpits."

Blavatsky then whips out her wand and points it at Daniel.

"Somnolencia salchicha sabrosa!" she screams.

A dart of pure golden light shoots out of the end of her wand and hits Daniel right in the middle of his forehead. In less than a half a second his head has sunk down to his arms on his desk and he is snoring peacefully.

The class breaks out into a round of applause.

"Make sure you get the pronunciation just right when you cast the spell" Blavataksy advises as she walks over to Daniel and tickles him under the armpits.

"He he he! What happened?" says Daniel, confused.

The class splits into pairs and you practice sending each other to sleep. Because Daniel is still a bit drowsy you go first, pointing your wand at his forehead just as the teacher did:

"Somnolencia salchicha sabrosa..." you repeat carefully.

You feel a wonderful feeling of magical _alertness_ gathering in your tummy. In an instant it has whooshed up out of your arm, channelled by the wand into a golden dart that strikes Daniel on the forehead, for the second time in as many minutes.

In no time at all he is asleep and snoring again.

"I did it!" you shout. "The magic spell worked!"

Delighted with your success you tickle Daniel under the armpits. As he wakes up giggling you try hard to memorise the spell 'Somnolencia salchicha sabrosa' - you never know when it may come in handy.
choice_1_text: Murmuring the words of the spell to yourself, you go back to the school hall.
title: Spelling trouble

content:
The first kid to step forward is a boy named Snako Malboy from Snakefang house. Azog is perched on your shoulder and hisses in satisfaction as the pale boy approaches nervously. 

Snako signs his name in your register and then utters a cry of alarm as Azog leaps onto his neck and sinks his sharp spider fangs into his ear lobe. But it is only to extract a harmless DNA sample from the boy's blood, and when the other children realise this more and more of them approach in the hopes that they too will be made superhuman.

Then the hard work begins. 

With Azog, Daniel Colliers Wood and some of the more intelligent Ravenwing students you lock yourselves into a magical laboratory with the childrens' DNA samples. Collecting additional DNA from your insect army it is not long before you have created a powerful hybrid human-insect DNA serum, which you further refine into substrains for isolated traits: wings, antenna, hairy legs and so on.

By the time of school assembly on the following day you are ready. 

"Fellow students!" you shout, holding up your hands for silence. "All those who signed up for the human-insect hybridisation program come to front of the hall!"

You instruct them to line up according to whichever insect enhancement they desire: one line for wings, another line for antennae, another for hairy legs and so on. 

Each student swallows a magical pill the size and shape of a bluebottle and the transformations begin! 

Yells of laughter and delight fill the great hall as the students sprout translucent wings out of their backs, long probing antennae from their foreheads and grow great ugly black hairs on their legs.

In no time at all they are zooming through the air, climbing up the walls and leaping from table to table, reveling in their amazing new powers - the age of the superhuman has begun! 

But now it is time for the second - secret - part of your plan.

You and Daniel sneak back to the magical laboratory as the other kids fool around in the great hall. Even Azog doesn't know what you have planned now.

Back at the laboratory you quickly combine the different DNA serums into a single super fluid and mix in two hairs, freshly plucked from each of your heads. The liquid turns electric blue and froths golden bubbles. 

You pour it into two matching goblets and hand one to Daniel. Clinking the glasses you look Daniel in the eye. 

"See you on the next brain plane."

"I'll drink to that!" he replies and you both drain your glasses. 

The other students and Azog have all of them been deceived. Into each serum you secretly added some termite DNA which has created a hive mind link directly to your and Daniel's brains, activated by your drink. 

The brain power of all the children has been added to yours making you and Daniel 100 times cleverer than the cleverest person in human history. As an added bonus, every insect, and each student, is now under your direct control.

Too late the children flying around the Great Hall with their fantastic insect wings realise their predicament and their cries of dismay ring out.

You and Daniel smile at each other, a smile of superman intelligence and understanding. Communicating by pure brainwaves you speak directly into his mind:

"This experiment has been most satisfactory - what shall be our next invention?"


CONGRATULATIONS YOU HAVE ACHIEVED THE SUPERHUMAN MASTERMIND ENDING
title: Epilogue

content:
"Yes there is something I need to talk to you about Arthur, something very important," says Slumblebore. 

"Ever since the end of the last school term I have sensed an evil presence in the school. An evil presence that is growing stronger by the day. All that I have been able to determine is that it is coming from the school dungeons. But _what_ it is and _where_ exactly it is down there I do not know. Whatever it is, is beyond my power."

Slumblebore looks at you directly, his bushy eyebrows waggling. 

"This is where you come in Arthur. I need you to investigate what is going on in the dungeon. And deal with it."

"You want me to go to the dungeon!" you ask, amazed. "But you said at the school dinner that the dungeon was forbidden and no children were to go anywhere near!"

"Yes but Arthur don't you see? I can't just go around encouraging all the children to go down into the dungeons. Imagine if anything happened to them? Their parents would take Hogsnorts School to court, the fines could be crippling! No far better if you could just handle this quietly. And don't tell anyone that I told you to go down there."

"But I don't know hardly any magic!" you exclaim, "I've only just started magic school!"

"I agree you should learn one or two spells before you venture down. Pay attention to your teachers! What they teach you could save your life."

"But why me sir? Why not ask one of the older children to do it? Why don't _you_ do it?"

"There is one thing I haven't told you Arthur. In the summer holidays I discovered an ancient prophecy concerning the school. It was written on a scroll that was so old that as soon as I touched it it turned to dust. It said: 

::: text-poem
'_When darkness falls across your school. 
And evil threatens to rise and rule,  
When monsters lurk around school ground. 
The boy called Arthur must be found._'
:::

"Your coming has been foretold. If the prophecy is correct, only you can save us."

"And if you do this thing Arthur," Slumblebore adds, "I will personally award one million points for Lionpaw House."
choice_1_text: "What must I do?" you ask, with a determined look in your eye.
choice_2_text: "This is totally crazy," you exclaim. "You want me to fight an evil monster all on my own just because of some old poem? I'm just a kid!" As you leave the office Slumblebore calls after you: "I'll be here waiting for you Arthur, when you find your courage."
title: The prophecy

content:
You and your new friend Daniel Colliers-Wood join the line of Ravenwing students flocking out of the dining hall. The older Ravenwings lead the way which is just as well as the route is so complicated you would have never found it on your own.

Down winding stone staircases that never seem to end. Over sloping flagstones that spiral upward for miles. Across innumerable stone courtyards where your steps echo from the walls.

You pass by magical stained-glass windows in which the colours change over time, making images of dragons breathing flames, or towering magicians leap over tree tops. You walk through dark stone tunnels which are only illuminated by occasional flickering torches.

At last your heart lifts as your weary feet take you to a stone archway framed in the Ravenwing colours of blue and copper.

"We've arrived everyone," announces a sixth year student from the front of the line. "First years, welcome to your home away from home for the next six years. Everyone else, welcome back! And remember - it is Wingers only who are allowed in here. The tree won't allow anybody else in."

"What tree?" you whisper to Daniel. "Is there a tree blocking the way?"

Daniel just shrugs his shoulders, his eyes wide.

Together with the other students you walk under the archway and you notice that the stone is carved in the shape of two intertwined wings. At the top of the arch is a carved-stone raven's head, beak open and pointing downwards.

On the other side of the arch is a stone staircase which you begin to climb.

As you climb you notice something strange: the air smells different, warmer somehow. And the stone steps themselves seem to be becoming softer, their edges smoother.

After a few more turns of the spiral stone staircase you realise that somehow the stone is morphing into a staircase made out of a single piece of wood. But it doesn't seem to be carved wood. Instead it is wood that has _grown_ into this shape.

You keep walking upwards until your legs feel too tired to take another step, when at last you emerge into... a vast timber... room? But this enormous space is made of the same strange flowing, growing wood as the staircase. Then you realise where you are and your jaw drops open.

You and the other Ravenwing students have emerged into the inside of an impossibly giant living tree.

The hollow inside space - the tree trunk - where you are standing soars up seemingly forever. Living wooden ramps and stairs crisscross the space above your head, and you can see doorways scattered in the trunk at different levels. And lining the inside of the tree trunk for as far as you can see are what must be miles and miles of bookshelves, covered in books of every shape and colour imaginable.

"Arthur", says Daniel, "look at all those _books_!"

"That's right youngsters," says a kindly looking student a couple of years older than you. "This is the heart of the Ravenwing House Tower and the heart of the tree: the library. This is the largest library in the world. The largest in the magical _and_ non-magical world," he adds proudly. "Every book that has ever been written and every book that _will ever be written_ is somewhere on these shelves."

"But how do you find the one you want among so many?" you ask.

"Easy!" says the boy. "Just watch!"

Shaping a small hole with his lips, he lets out a warbling musical whistle. From high up in the trunk there is an answering warble, and you realise that perched up there is a whole flock of emerald green parrots. One of them flies down to your new companion and lands on his shoulder with a gentle squawk.

"What's your name first year?" the boy asks you with a smile.

"Arthur Otley."

"Ok. Polybius, bring me a book by Arthur Otley." The parrot launches himself into the air and flies up into the tree trunk.

You realise that Polybius must be the name of the parrot but you don't understand why the boy is asking for a book written by you. "But I haven't written any books," you explain.

"You mean you haven't written any books _yet_!" replies the boy. "Remember that this library contains _all_ books including those that will be written in the future."

With that Polybius the parrot swoops down through the air, and drops a book from his claws into your hands. You look at the cover, which reads: "Adventures with Dragons, by Arthur Otley."

A huge smile appears on your face. "You mean I will write this?" you ask the boy.

"Of course you will, and if you are not sure _what_ to write, you can just read it to find out."

As your head spins with possibilities, Daniel tugs on your sleeve. "Hey Arthur, let's go and find our bedrooms."

You allow Daniel to lead you off up one of the spiralling wooden ramps to a doorway high above the tree trunk floor. Above the doorway is a sign saying "BEDROOMS".

The doorway leads to a wide wooden corridor which you realise must be the inside of a branch of this great tree. Every now and again to the left and right are doorways with the names of students written above them. After a short while you come across a doorway that says "ARTHUR OTLEY" above it, next to one with "DANIEL COLLIERS-WOOD" above it.

You go in and find yourself in a beautiful cosy little living room with some flow-wood armchairs and a sofa, leading to a spacious bathroom and a bedroom. As you go into the bedroom you can see the sun sinking below the horizon through an open window: the grounds of Hogsnorts School are far below you. At the centre of the bedroom is a luxurious circular bed. On top of the pillow is a foil-wrapped mint chocolate and a little raven cuddly toy.

You take off your shoes, throw yourself backwards on the bed and munch on the mint chocolate. Yes I think I can be happy here, you say to yourself, as you drift off to sleep with a smile on your face.
choice_1_text: Go to sleep and wake up in the morning
title: The Ravenwing House Tower

content:
You raise your hand and most of the other children do the same. 

"Brilliant!" says Professor Jape, "How about this one."

"Why do aliens find it so much bother to drink a cup of tea?"

You and the other students look politely blank faced. 

"Flying saucers!" says Jape with a laugh. "D'you get it? Eh?"

"That's a terrible joke!" you whisper to Snako.

"Ok children, next one: 

"Why did the toilet paper roll down the stairs of the Snakefang house tower? Come on, any guesses? No? 

"To get to the bottom! You know: bottom. Bottom! Your bum! You wipe your bum with toilet paper! Oh you lot are hopeless."

"That's pretty good actually" Snako whispers to you.

"Right next one. Do you ever file your toe nails? Anyone?" shouts out Professor Jape thoroughly enjoying himself now. "Yes? I don't, I just throw them away! I don't file them, I throw them away, d'you see?"

A few groans and shouts of laughter in the room.

"Who was the fastest runner of all time? Adam, he was the first in the human race!"

"Right, listen to this." Jape continues. "There was a football match in the jungle. The elephants versus the insects. Eleven a side. The match starts and the elephants are _all over_ the insects. Within five minutes they've already scored two goals. At half time it's 21 nil to the elephants. Then at half time the insects bring on a new player: a centipede. This centipede is _amazing!_. His feet move so quickly the elephants just can't stop him. In four minutes he's got a hat-trick. In ten minutes he's got a hat-trick of hat-tricks. When the game finishes the insects win 28 goals to 21. Now then, after the game the captain of the elephants goes over to congratulate the captain of the insects on their victory. 'But what I don't understand' he says, 'is why didn't you start the match with the centipede?' 'Well' replies the insect captain, 'we would do but it takes 'im forty-five minutes to get his boots on!'"

Professor Jape bursts into uncontrollable high pitched giggling and lots of the other children laugh too. 

"Right children," says Jape. "That's all we've got time for in this lesson. I hope you had a good laugh, I know I did. See you next time."
choice_1_text: You go back to the main hall to decide what to learn next, wondering if all your lessons will be this fun!
title: Jape's joke time

content:
The next day all the children are called to the school hall for a special announcement.

As you take your seats at the house tables you notice that the ceiling has been enchanted to a beautiful sky blue with fluffy clouds scudding past on one side and a fleet of giant floating zeppelins racing each other on the other. 

"Students," announces Slumblebore from the front of the hall. "I have a very special announcement. Yesterday, unbeknownst to us, we were threatened by a vast and evil insect horde gathering in the school dungeon."

Slumblebore casts a severe glance at professor Knid, who looks down sheepishly at the table. 

"We were saved thanks to the bravery, resourcefulness and pure gumption of one boy.

"That boy is Arthur Otley."

You feel your cheeks go red as all the students in the school turn round to get a look at you and you hear whispers of "yes that's him", "defeated the insects single handed!", "still just a first year!", and "wouldn't mess with that fella!".

"In recognition of his outstanding services to Hogsnorts School I am pleased to award: one million points to Snakefang House!"

Deafening cheers come from the Snakefang House students all around you.

"Did you hear that?" cries Snake Malboy. "A million points! Last year the Lionpaw house only got 600 points for the whole year! Now no-one will be able to beat us to the House Cup!"

"What is more," continues Slumblebore, "any unused Snakefang House points will carry over from one year to the next. Which by my calculation means that Snakefang House will win the House Cup for approximately the next... one hundred years." Slumblebore beams at you through his beard.

"Lastly I hereby announce a new order of wizardry: the Order of the Arthropods. Arthur I grant you first class membership of the Order. Three cheers for Arthur Otley, hero of the school and founding member of the Order of the Arthropods!"

The cheers ring out over and over again. The Snakefang students raise you up on your shoulders and carry you round and round the school hall in triumph shouting "Hooray for Arthur, hero of the school!"

CONGRATULATIONS - YOU HAVE ACHIEVED THE HERO OF THE SCHOOL ENDING
title: Epilogue

content:
Slumblebore's office is easy to find, you just follow the signs pointing the way. When you reach it you see that the door is slightly ajar - and there is a light still on inside. Perhaps Slumblebore has gone to bed and forgotten to turn the light out.

You motion Kensley to wait outside and she nods vigorously. "Be careful Arthur!" she whispers, "don't leave me on my own for too long!".

You push on the half open door and immediately hear a voice:

"Come in Arthur." It's Slumblebore - you've been rumbled!

"Don't worry," Slumblebore says as if reading your thoughts. "I have been waiting for you to come. I wanted to talk with you."

You walk into Slumblebore's office and look around you. Every inch of space has been used. Leather bound books on bookshelves line the walls. Paintings with ornate golden frames are hung all around, and ancient Hogsnorts headteachers stare down at you, blinking and sniffing. From the ceiling hang silver cages containing magical golden birds, tiny jewelled monkeys no bigger than your thumb and baby dragons curled up and sleeping. On the floor pentagrams have been marked out in yellow chalk and you almost trip over a live weasel dressed in a little red waistcoat that must be Slumbebore's pet. You resist the urge to stroke its cute little furry head.

Slumblebore himself is sitting behind a massive wooden desk, piled high with manuscripts, scrolls, steaming goblets, plates of watermelon, little bowls of nuts and weasel droppings.

"Care for a raisin?" Slumblebore offers, brushing some weasel droppings onto the floor and proffering you a bowl.

"Err no, thank you," you reply, not entirely convinced that the bowl is 100% raisins.

"Arthur, I'm glad you have come. There is something very serious for us to discuss, which concerns the safety of the entire school. I need your help. But first tell me, how are you settling into the school? Do you feel happy in your new house?"
choice_1_text: Yes it is very nice thank you, you reply. "But what did you want to talk to me about?"
choice_2_text: Well, I do like the school, you say. "But I'm not sure that I am in the right house. I don't feel like I really belong there."
title: Slumblebore's office
choice_3_text: You reach out a hand to touch the weasel, it just looks so cute you can't help yourself.

content:
You find yourself face to face with a trio of bombardier beetles, who seem to be guarding the way. 

"Wow look at the size of those things!" says Aaron. "Do you think they are friendly."

One of them makes an angry chittering sound. Even though you don't speak beetle you are pretty sure this beetle doesn't like you. 

The three beetles turn around in the corridor to face away from you. 

"Hey look they're running away!" shouts Aaron.

Suddenly there is a loud popping sound and a steam of superheated liquid shoots out of the beetles' bottoms. 

"Duck!" you cry, and you and Aaron throw yourself to one side. The liquid misses you by inches. The stone flagstone bubbles and fizzes where the liquid struck it.

You both pick yourself up off the floor and scramble back round the corner for safety.

"That was too close," you say. "We need to find a way to get past those things."

You think hard, there must be a spell that you can use. Some spell that puts them out of action for a while so you can sneak past.

After a moment, with grim determination, you decide. You leap out from your hiding place, your wand at the ready.
choice_1_text: Yelling "Tweetle beetle bottle battle!"
choice_2_text: Shouting "Paraguas pronto!"
title: Beetle battle
choice_3_text: Screaming "Die beetles, die."
choice_4_text: Crying "Somnolencia salchicha sabrosa!"
choice-5-text: This is all getting a bit hairy, you decide that the best course of action will be to retreat and come back tomorrow, having learnt some anti-beetle spells.

content:
Joining a gang of other Snakefang students you head off on the long winding route back to the Hogsnorts Great Hall to get your dinner.

You take a seat at the Snakefang table (after a minor scuffle with some thick headed Lionpaw students) and look around amazed.

Tonight Slumblebore has enchanted the walls and ceiling of the Great Hall to look like the sub-tropical, volcano strewn world of the Jurassic. The effect is made even more magical by enchanting the floor to make it appear as if the Great Hall is strapped to the back of a huge lumbering sauropod - a brontosaurus perhaps - the chairs ensorcelled to vibrate with every lumbering step.

You stare wide eyed at the other giants of the sauropod herd to your left and ride, their long necks stretching forward as you cross an ancient Jurassic plain.

"Don't forget to eat Arthur!" Snako reminds you, elbowing you in the side.

You look down to see yet another incredible feast. 

An entire flock of roast swans laid out in a row along the long table. Huge piles of frankfurter sausages, sizzled a beautiful golden brown. Crispy potato chips carved into all manner of spirals, whorls, and helixes. Pears smothered in mayonnaise. Baked bananas wrapped in delicious streaky bacon, stuffed with ketchup. Profiteroles the size of your head, full of light fluffy cream.

It is all so delicious you can't stop an involuntary slobber which you quickly wipe from your chin with the table cloth.

You cram food into your mouth and gulp it down.

When you are full you have a brisk food fight with Lionpaw table, pelting them with profiteroles and bread soaked in gravy - they return the attack with giant strawberries and chicken drumsticks. You shout with laughter when you hit one of the Lionpaw students, a boy called Aaron, full on the face with a giant profiterole and cream explodes everywhere. Snako gets hit in the eye with a boiled potato.

The food fight ends when the dinosaur enchantment on the walls and ceiling suddenly transforms into a battle scene as a gang of huge tyrannosaurus rexes charge from the side at the sauropods that you are riding. You scream and shout with the other students - Slumblebore's enchantment looks so real you can't help ducking as a huge t-rex slashes at you with claws the size of hockey sticks.

Chairs are leaning crazily as the sauropod carrying the Dining Hall tries to evade the ferocious T-Rex attack. The sauropods moan distress cries and fight back with tail whips and neck slams. Several Hedgehog House students vomit on the floor, overcome with fright and motion sickness.

It's complete pandemonium, which ends with the T-Rexes fleeing, defeated but blood dripping from their jaws where they have bitten off hunks of sauropod flesh.

"Snakehouse rules yah ssss!" shouts Snako at the top of his voice at the retreating T-Rexes, overcome with excitement, sticking out his tongue and flapping his hands by the side of his head.

This signals the end of the best dinner you have ever had.

Turning to Snako you say.
choice_1_text: I'm pooped, let's go back to the Tower and get some rest.
choice_2_text: "Hey, let's sneak out and explore the castle! It's too early to go to bed just yet."
title: Dinner time

content:
"Let's just walk over the woodlice," you say to Daniel. "I mean, we _are_ about a million times heavier than them. We _should_ just be able to squash them as we go."

"I don't know Arthur," replies Daniel, a look of trepidation in his eyes. "Do you really think it will work?"

In answer you take a determined stride forwards, towards the waiting woodlice hordes. They look back at you from their tiny little compound eyes, their little antenna waving in the air. Daniel sets off behind you.

The first couple of steps pass without mishap. A few of the woodlouse stragglers on the edge of the multitudinous crowd are flattened under the soles of your shoes and you smile, your confidence growing.

But then, as if some kind of telepathic signal passed between the woodlice, in exactly the same moment, there is a whisper of chitin and they simultaneously roll into tight balls - their defensive posture.

You try to stop your forward momentum but it is too late.

Your left foot propels itself through the air and comes down. Onto hundreds and hundreds of little woodlice balls. It is like stepping on a tray of marbles - you don't stand a chance. Your foot rolls on the little balls, grip on the floor hopelessly lost. It shoots forwards and your body shoots backwards - and downwards.

"Aaaargh!" you cry out, landing on the floor with a terrible crash, banging your head. Your fall has crushed to death thousands of woodlice but it is not enough, there are millions more to take their place.

As you slip into unconsciousness, you are vaguely aware of Daniel falling next to you, like a felled tree among the woodlice. You are not sure, but you think you can hear millions of tiny cheers.

Then - everything goes dark.
choice_1_text: You stay unconscious for a while.
title: Balls up

content:
You wake up feeling refreshed and content. You wonder why you are feeling so cheerful and then you remember: you are a pupil in the Hogsnorts school of magic, and have been chosen for the best house - Lionpaw. You have already made a good friend, Aaron Bleezely, and you have your own four-poster bed with an ensuite bathroom. Life is looking good!

You jump out of bed and pull on your wizard's robes.

"Aaron" you shout as you walk out onto the staircase, "are you up?"

At that moment you see Aaron running up the stairs towards you in his swimming trunks.

"Hey Arthur, you woke up at last! I've been playing in the waterslides for the last hour. The Lionpaw House Tower is soooo cool. What shall we do today? I know there are lessons but I'm sure no-one will notice if we skip them for a day."
choice_1_text: You explain to Aaron that your really want to learn some magic spells and that you can do waterslides together some other time.
choice_2_text: He's got a point you think. Magic school will last for six years. Surely bunking off for one day won't do any harm?
title: Wake up call

content:
Dashing round the corner you raise your wand and yell "Paraguas pronto!"

To your astonishment, from the end of your wand pops out a translucent sparkly golden umbrella.

In a flash it opens up - it is big enough to cover both you and Aaron, which is just as well because in that same moment there is another popping sound and three more splotches of superheated acid from the beetles' bottoms fly through the air towards you.

Splat splat splat!

The acid hits the magical golden umbrella, protecting you from harm. 

But not the golden umbrella. In a few moments the acid has dissolved it to nothing, just a little bit of umbrella handle is left poking out of the end of your wand. 

The three giant bombardier beetles raise their rear ends at you, and make menacing chittering noises. 

"Run away!" shouts Aaron, "We're sitting ducks!"

You both turn back and flee, rounding the corner as more blobs of acid hit the wall behind you. 

"That wasn't exactly what I wanted the spell to do..." you explain to Aaron, embarrassed.
choice_1_text: You catch your breath and reassess the situation
title: Taking cover

content:
You raise your hand and most of the other children do the same. 

"Brilliant!" says Professor Jape, "How about this one."

"What did the science teacher use to freshen her breath?"

You and the other students look politely blank faced. 

"Experimints!" says Jape with a laugh. "D'you get it? Experi-mints?"

"That's a terrible joke!" you whisper to Daniel.

"Ok children, next one: 

"Why don't scientists trust atoms? 

"Because they make up everything!"

"I quite like that one" Daniel whispers to you.

"Right next one. A boy comes up to me, he says: I think my maths teacher loves me. Well why do you think that then? I ask him. Well, he says, she keeps putting little kisses next to all my sums!" Professor Jape bursts out laughing, thoroughly enjoying himself. "D'you see? She keeps on putting kisses by the sums - you like crosses because this little fella keeps getting him sums wrong, hahahaha."

A few groans and shouts of laughter in the room.

"Right, listen to this." Jape continues. "There was this fella Nigel who worked in a zoo, mucking out the cages and whatnot. Well one day the orangutan got sick and I'm sorry to say, he died. Now this orangutan was the star attraction, so the owner of the zoo says to this fella: 'Listen Nigel: I want you to dress up in an orangutan suit. The visitors will never know the difference. Without my orangutan star attraction I'm worried the zoo is going to have to close down.' So Nigel put on the orangutan suit and at first felt very self-conscious with all the visitors staring at him and laughing whenever he did anything. But after a while he started to enjoy it, being an orangutan, entertaining the crowd. He started swinging on the ropes going higher and higher, but then... he went too high by mistake and accidentally swung over the wall into the next enclosure - the lion enclosure! Well Nigel was terrified, and the lion - he looked furious. Nigel forgot all about pretending to be an orangutan and started shouting out 'Help! Help! Someone save me!'. The lion gave an almighty roar, and charged over to Nigel. The lion put his face right next Nigel and whispered: 'keep quiet you nincompoop or you'll give us all away!'"

Professor Jape bursts into uncontrollable high pitched giggling and lots of the other children laugh too.

"Right children," says Jape. "That's all we've got time for in this lesson. I hope you had a good laugh, I know I did. See you next time."
choice_1_text: You go back to the main hall to decide what to learn next, wondering if all your lessons will be this fun!
title: Jape's joke time

content:
Slumblebore's office is easy to find, you just follow the signs pointing the way. When you reach it you see that the door is slightly ajar - and there is a light still on inside. Perhaps Slumblebore has gone to bed and forgotten to turn the light out.

You motion Aaron to wait outside and he nods vigorously. "Be careful!" he whispers.

You push on the half open door and immediately hear a voice:

"Come in Arthur." It's Slumblebore - you've been rumbled!

"Don't worry," Slumblebore says as if reading your thoughts. "I have been waiting for you to come. I wanted to talk with you."

You walk into Slumblebore's office and look around you. Every inch of space has been used. Leather bound books on bookshelves line the walls. Paintings with ornate golden frames are hung all around, and ancient Hogsnorts headteachers stare down at you, blinking and sniffing. From the ceiling hang silver cages containing magical golden birds, tiny jewelled monkeys no bigger than your thumb and baby dragons curled up and sleeping. On the floor pentagrams have been marked out in yellow chalk and you almost trip over a weasel dressed in a little red waistcoat that must be Slumblebore's pet.

Slumblebore himself is sitting behind a massive wooden desk, piled high with manuscripts, scrolls, steaming goblets, plates of watermelon, little bowls of nuts and weasel droppings.

"Care for a raisin?" Slumblebore offers, brushing some weasel droppings onto the floor and proffering you a bowl.

"Err no, thank you," you reply, not entirely convinced that the bowl is 100% raisins.

"Arthur, I'm glad you have come. There is something very serious for us to discuss, which concerns the safety of the entire school. I need your help. But first tell me, how are you settling into the school? Do you feel happy in your new house?"
choice_1_text: "Yes it is amazing," you reply. "But what did you want to talk to me about?"
choice_2_text: "Well, I do like the school," you say. "But I'm not sure that I am in the right house. I don't feel like I really belong there."
title: Slumblebore's office
choice_3_text: You reach out a hand to pet the weasel, as you ponder Slumbebore's question.

content:
You raise your wand, point it at the woodlice menacingly and shout loudly:

"Dispara dinosaurio demente!"

From out of the end of your wand comes a faint but growing roaring sound, like an angry lion. The noise grows louder and louder until it is so loud it hurts your ears. 

"Arthur, what did you do?" asks Aaron on alarm. 

"I don't..." you begin, but before you can finish your sentence, a huge golden dinosaur head somehow _forces_ it's way out of the tip of your wand, and roars again deafeningly.

"ROAR!!!"

"Did I never tell you that I'm terrified of giant angry tyrannosaurus rexes!" yells out Aaron, too petrified to move.

But there's nothing you can do, the spell has been cast. The enormous magical t-rex squeezes its way out of your wand and charges its way towards the woodlice, waggling its ridiculous stunted front legs in a demented fashion. 

It launches itself at the nearest woodlouse which has no time to react.

But instead of crushing the woodlouse in its banana sized teeth, the t-rex - impossibly - just bounces off.

It roars and tries again, with the same result. 

Then it hits you - woodlice are completely immune to magic. 

The dinosaur appears to understand this too. It looks around for a better target. And it's crazy little red eyes fix on you and Aaron.

With a sense of horror you realise that the t-rex is now hunting _you_!

The rabid dinosaur leaps at you and Aaron but instead of eating you it flings you both into the stone wall on each side and you bump your head painfully. The t-rex stomps up the corridor before disappearing a puff of gold stars as the magic wears off.

As you slide down the wall and into unconsciousness, you can see the millions of woodlice waving their little antennae. As you close your eyes you think: are they laughing?
choice_1_text: You lie down unconscious for an indeterminate length of time.
title: Magical mayhem

content:
In front of you is a corridor. The corridor is festooned from floor to ceiling with spider web strands. These strands are so thick it is almost impossible to see along the passage.

The way is blocked.

Kensley turns to you with moist eyes. "What are we going to do Arthur?"

You raise your wand and concentrate.
choice_1_text: Push the spider web out of the way with your hands. It's just cobwebs after all.
choice_2_text: Extending your wand arm you exclaim: "Vamos varita vencer vistosamente!"
title: Dungeon crawl
choice_3_text: Tonto tijeras trae tiempo! you shout out, waving your wand energetically.
choice_4_text: I wonder if this will work, you think, holding your wand aloft and chanting "Wobble wibble webby wane."
choice-5-text: This is just too stressful. You decide to head back to the house tower, learn a bit more magic and come back another day better prepared.

content:
"I'm Arthur Otley and I want to learn some spells" you say to Professor Blavatsky.

"Ah so impatient. And yet this impatience stops you learning about yourself. I can see that you are very far from self control as yet."

The teacher stands up and raises one hand.

"But do not worry, any of you. Because we will start with a simple meditation session to help you gain control."

You groan inwardly. This sounds boring. 

"Close your eyes everyone," begins Professor Blavatsky. "Make sure you are comfortable in your seats. Now I want you to focus on your breathing. Breathe in. Breathe out. Breathe in... and breathe out.

"Feel the breath flowing into your nostrils. Concentrate on the sensation. Do you feel your nose hairs tickling? Perhaps a small bogey flapping around in your nasal passage? Just think about the breath, how it feels."

Despite yourself you feel your awareness sharpening, and you do indeed feel a small bogey in your nostril wobbling around as you breathe in and out. 

"Now I want you to think about a special number. The special number is 42. A four and then a two. Forty two. This number is not just a number it is also a place. A location. A place of calm that you can always turn to in moments of difficulty or stress. 

"This number 42 is a place within yourself, but it is a real place too that anyone can reach, if they just turn to that number... the number 42. As you turn to 42, just keep your thumb here so you know where to come back to."

Amazingly you feel a sensation as if you are floating somehow, except with your thumb stuck down in front of you. Concentrating fiercely you try with all your might to turn to 42. You float away...

...

"Did anyone manage to meditate and reach 42?" asks Madam Blavatsky. 

You definitely feel you went... somewhere. You _think_ this is what Professor Blavatsky meant.

"Any time you find yourself in need of quiet and peace, just repeat this meditation exercise and think of the number 42 and you will find a place of calm and relaxation - but keep your thumb right where you are and you will be able to turn back whenever you want."

"Class dismissed! We will meet again."
choice_1_text: As if in a daze you and the other children rise slowly to your feet and walk out of the classroom. You do feel as if maybe you know yourself a little better now.
title: Inner peace

content:
The clock strikes one... two... three.

The golden glow shining all around you gets stronger and stronger and soon you have to shut your eyes to the blinding golden light.

After a momentary sensation of vertigo, as if you have all of a sudden _fallen_, you sense that the golden light is fading away.

Opening your eyes you find you are at the bottom of a great stone well, with a circle of light far above. You realise that you have magically transported back to Percy the Picking Pigeon's hole in the Hogsnort's Great Hall, just as Slumblebore said you would. Somehow you know that you have also travelled back in time to before, when you had just arrived at the school. You are that Arthur once again in Percy's hole, but this time you can make a new choice.

"Well Arthur," says a voice directly to your brain. "What will you choose, coo coo." It is Percy the giant pigeon and you see again his giant yellow eyes staring at you.

This time you know you will make a good choice...
choice_1_text: I want to be in Lionpaw House, the home of the brave, you think hard to yourself.
choice_2_text: For me it is Ravenwing House, you think, I want to learn and explore.
title: Another chance
choice_3_text: Snakefang House for me, I want to rise to the top and be the best, you say in your mind.
choice_4_text: I want to be in Hedgehog House please, you think, I want to have a nice time and stay out of trouble.

content:
"Let's just walk over the woodlice," you say to Snako. "I mean, we _are_ about a million times heavier than them. We _should_ just be able to squash them as we go."

"I don't know Arthur," replies Kensley, looking very uncomfortable. "Are you sure this will work?"

In answer you take a tentative step forwards, towards the waiting woodlice hordes. They look back at you (do they have eyes?) their little antenna waving in the air. Kensley sets off behind you with a little whimper.

The first couple of steps pass without mishap. A few of the woodlouse stragglers on the edge of the multitudinous crowd are flattened under the soles of your shoes and you wince at the crunch.

But then, as if some kind of telepathic signal passed between the woodlice, in exactly the same moment, there is a whisper of chitin and they simultaneously roll into tight balls - their defensive posture.

You try to stop your forward momentum but it is too late.

Your left foot propels itself through the air and comes down. Onto hundreds and hundreds of little woodlice balls.

It is like stepping on a tray of marbles - you don't stand a chance. Your foot rolls on the little balls, grip on the floor hopelessly lost. It shoots forwards and your body shoots backwards - and downwards.

"Aaaargh!" you cry out, landing on the floor with a terrible crash, banging your head. Your fall has crushed to death thousands of woodlice but it is not enough, there are millions more to take their place. 

As you slip into unconsciousness, you are vaguely aware of Kensley toppling over next to you, like a felled tree among the woodlice. You are not sure, but you think you can hear millions of tiny cheers.

Then - nothing.
choice_1_text: You stay unconscious for a while.
title: Balls up

content:
"Yeah we're in Snakefang House now, we can do whatever we like!" you say, as the two of you head down to the lava pool.

As you arrive in the central courtyard the other Snakefang students are leaving for your lessons, but not before one of them has explained to you that the lava pool is one end of a pipe that goes through the earth's crust directly down to the mantle 70 km below. Magically constructed by Sylvester Snakefang all those centuries ago with a knowledge that is now lost, it still serves as the central heating and waste disposal system of the Tower.

This gives you an idea, and you and Snako go back to your towers and return with an armful of food from your everlasting larders. You make a little pile of this next to the lava pool and take turns throwing stuff in and watching it burn. You particularly enjoy watching the chocolate frogs melting to a gloop and then bursting into flames. 

When you get bored of this you play with the snakes. They don't speak but they appear to understand everything you say, and soon you are playing tag, running and yelling with the snakes in hot pursuit.

Then you discover another doorway leading to a cavernous rock chamber full of indoor tennis and badminton courts and table tennis tables. You and Snako play a few rounds of table tennis leading to a two-all draw.

After another trip to the inexhaustible larder you decide to climb up the winding stone staircase to the very top of the house tower. When you reach the summit your legs feel like they can't take another step but you are rewarded with a view for miles and miles - hills and mountains and forests, with no buildings other than those of Hogsnorts in sight.

You and Snako amuse yourselves by throwing things off the edge and watching them fall. 

Finally you both go and chill out in your own tower, playing video games in which you run around shooting at each other.

It has been the best day ever.

But it isn't over yet! "Hey Arthur, Snako," shouts one anonymous pale-faced student, just returned from lessons. "Dinner time in the Great Hall!"
choice_1_text: Din-dins! You mouth already watering you join the other Snakefang students making their way to the centre of the school
choice_2_text: You are so tired, all you want to do is curl up in bed and sleep. You decide to go to bed instead.
title: Bunking off

To your astonishment, from the end of your wand pops out a translucent sparkly golden umbrella.

The three giant bombardier beetles raise their rear ends at you, and make menacing chittering noises. 

"Oh my goodness!" shouts Kensley, "Run away!"

"That wasn't _exactly_ what I wanted the spell to do..." you explain to Kensley, embarrassed.

title: Taking cover

content:
"Tonto tijeras trae tiempo!" you shout out, waving your wand above your head.

To your surprise, a golden pair of magical scissors shoots out of the end of your wand and strikes the ceiling, and golden threads arch through the stone above your head.

From the golden filaments in the roof, a flutter of beautiful golden snowflakes fall. Each one has an exquisitely perfect hexagonal symmetry.

When they land on your arms and head, they give you a warm tingling sensation and then disappear with a tinkling sound, like a tiny bell.

After a few moments the golden snow fall stops and the corridor returns to its previous gloomy state.

"Wow that was so beautiful Arthur" says Kensley. "But it didn't help much with the spiders web."
choice_1_text: You look up. Kensley's right. The spider web is still blocking your way. You will have to try something else.
title: A silly idea

content:
You cautiously reach out a hand to pet the weasel, who allows you to pat him gently on the head.

"Ah, you like my pet weasel do you? You like to pat him? Good: Wesley could do with a little affection now and again, couldn't you Wesley hmmm? You see Arthur," Slumblebore explains as you pat away, "Wesley was not always a weasel. He was not always called Wesley either. Let me explain. 

"Wesley used to be a real boy just like you Arthur. Then one day in an ill-tempered dispute with a fellow student about who had the fastest broomstick, he was transformed by magic into the weasel you see before you. Unfortunately the spell was permanent."

Wesley listens to all this intently, and he leaps onto Slumblebore's desk, chattering his teeth in rage and frustration.

"As Wesley was an orphan I realised that the kindest thing to do would be to adopt him as my pet. My tailor on Hippotomews specially made his red waistcoat and matching hat. And I decided to give him his new name: Wesley, because Wesley the Weasel has a rather pleasing ring to it, don't you think? His boy name before that was Gary, which would never do. Or possibly it was Barry.

"Ever since then he has lived with me. We get along famously although I must admit that his table manners are not all that they might be - he has an unfortunate habit of defecating in the raisins."

Wesley hangs his head, shamefacedly. 

"You can easily tell which is which though," says Slumblebore brightening. "The raisins have a smooth feel, whereas the droppings are more squishy. Unless Wesley has constipation - in which case they are crunchy.

"Why do I tell you all this Arthur? Because I want you to know that for all my students I will always be there for them. I will always be there for you, when you need help the most. Always, Arthur, always. Metaphorically. Just like I was for Barry. Or was it Larry.
choice_1_text: "Did you say you have something important to tell me sir?" you ask Slumblebore
title: Wesley the Weasel

content:
"Door lock undone, unlock door done!" you cry, flourishing your wand.

The door starts to shine with a magical golden glow.

"It's working!" you think to yourself, "I can't believe it worked!".
choice_1_text: Amazing! How did you know that was the password? Daniel cries out.
title: It's working!

content:
"What did you do that for?" you cry. "I thought he was your friend!"

"Eric Knid is... weak," replies Azog. "His only purpose was to help me lure the chosen one - you - down here. Now that you have arrived, I no longer need him."

Azog stepped delicately over the snoring form of Professor Knid and advances towards you.

"Just think Arthur. Together we could achieve so much. You, the chosen one with your one-of-a-kind wand and me with all the armies of the arthropods at my command! We could do anything. We could do everything!"

While Azog is talking he is getting steadily closer and closer to you. You find yourself mesmerised by his eight tiny compound eyes.

Perhaps you _should_ take a stand, remake the world with Azog and the insect hordes, take over the school... on the other hand if you were to stop Azog now you would be a hero and would surely win the house cup for Hedgehog House - didn't Slumblebore promise you a million points?

"You must choose now Arthur," says Azog quietly. "Are you with me? Or against me?"
choice_1_text: There is no way you are going to become the Boss of the Bugs - now you need to think of a way to wriggle out of this situation...
choice_2_text: "I'm with you Azog," you say and hold out your hand.
title: The final decision

content:
You sit still not wanting to encourage the professor, and none of the other students wants to disagree with him either. 

"Good. Good." says Professor Knid. "Now we are all agreed, I can tell you that today we will be studying the marvellous woodlouse. Flies, deliver the woodlice!"

At this command, a hundred or so flies detach themselves from Knid's cape, zoom over to a box on the professor's desk and pick up the woodlice, one between four flies. The flies then carry one woodlice to each student and drop it onto the desk in front of them. The flies buzz back to Professor Knid and reattach themselves to his cloak.

The little woodlouse on your desk appears disturbed at this unexpected flight. It takes one look at you then rolls up into a ball. 

"Now can anyone move their woodlouse using a magic spell?" asks Knid. "Try any magic spell that you know." 

You raise your wand, point it at the woodlouse and mumble "abracadabra" rather hopefully.

You are delighted to see a little sparkle of gold stars shoot out of the end of your wand. The sparkles hit the woodlouse... and bounce right off! The woodlouse is unmoved.

Looking around the classroom you can see that the other children are having no more success than you did.

Snako singed his own eyebrows when his lightning spell bounced off the woodlouse and hit him in the face. Kensley Potato's ice spell has frozen her desk into a solid block of ice but not touched the woodlouse. Brian Banana (another student from Hedgehog) has tried to make his woodlouse disappear but accidentally lost his wand in the process.

"The woodlouse, children, as you are discovering, is completely impervious to magic. So if you want to move the woodlouse you must first _understand_ the woodlouse. And the one thing that scares the woodlouse more than anything else is drying out. As soon as they lose their moisture they die. Now - look at this."

Professor Knid raises his wand in an impressively expansive gesture and recites: "Fiel fresa fusila fuego!"

A large flame whooshes out of the end of his wand and starts to bake the air around the woodlouse on his desk. Terrified of being dried out, the woodlouse unrolls and scuttles away as fast as he can.

"So we can see that _indirect_ magic can be powerful against even magic resistant creatures. And we didn't have to harm any arthropods in the process. Now children it's your turn. Wands at the ready!"

You look down at your cowering woodlouse and, aiming with your wand, recite the words of the spell: 

"Fiel fresa fusila fuego!"

From the tips of your fingers to the ends of your toes you can feel a powerful magic charge building in your body. It concentrates in your chest and then zooms along your arm and out of your wand in a very impressive jet of flame. 

You are overjoyed at the result, the first time you have cast such a powerful spell. Just think what you could do with such magic! Just imagine how frightened people will be of your powers!

The woodlouse feels the magical flames heat the air and desk around him, and scarpers.

"I did it!" you cry, and commit the words of the spell to your memory: fiel fresa fusila fuego.
choice_1_text: Feeling delighted you head back to the hall to decide what to do next
title: Knid's spell

content:
You leap out of the clock just in time, you could already feel the magic sucking you down.

Breathing hard you look back at the clock face and see the hands of the clock spinning madly backwards.

"You have changed your mind about changing your mind have you?" Slumblebore observes, his bushy eyebrows raised. "Well you can come and see me at any time and change your mind again if you want."

"I... I... I think I don't want to leave Hedgehog just yet," you stammer. You are not quite sure why you changed your mind at the last minute, but it just didn't feel... right.

"Well as you are not going anywhere just yet, let's get talking about the problem we have right now," says Slumblebore. "I'm talking of course about what we are going to do about the evil presence in the school dungeon. I fear it is something that may threaten the very existence of Hogsnorts."
choice_1_text: You sit down in a chair next to Slumblebore's desk and prick up your ears.
title: Just in time
