content:
You realise that _this_ is your destiny, to command the insect horde, to lead them.

You hold out your hand to Azog, who extends a spindly leg and climbs up your arm and onto your shoulder.

"Well done Arthur" says Azog, "You have chosen... wisely."

Millions upon millions of insects are looking at you with their two, four or eight compound eyes, eyes on the sides of their heads, eyes on stalks, all waiting. Waiting for your command.

"Insects!" you exclaim. "Arthropods! Follow me!"

Looking back, the rest of that night seems more like a fantastic dream than reality. 

You lead the insect army up through the passageways out of the dungeon and into the school. But instead of leading them to the centre of the school as Azog expected, you show them the way to Hedgehog House tower. 

From there the whole streaming mass of ants, spiders, earwigs, woodlice and beetles emerges onto the cool night air of the hillside where the Hoggers live in their holes. 

"But Arthur," protests Azog. "I thought we were taking over the school!"

"No," you replied simply. "Fighting only creates more fighting. Where will it end? What we need is peace."

You carry on walking, and hear the whispers of the insects as they follow you: "peeece" they say, "peeeeeece".

Finally reaching the end of the lane of Hogger Holes you instruct them to dig. 

Working together, before the sun has come up, the insects excavate a magnificent, glorious Hogger Hole of their own. While the door looks normal, and the initial tunnel is cosy enough to deceive the casual visitor - with umbrella stands and varnished wooden chairs with green velvet seats - soon the tunnel branches out into smaller and smaller passages, until they match the size of the insects that will live in them.

When the labour is complete, you turn to the tired, muddy, but happy insect multitude, and smile.

"Insects," you say, "welcome home."
choice_1_text: One year later...
title: The Order of the Athropods

content:
You remember that woodlice are one of the few creatures that are completely immune to magic of any kind, and decide to cast a heat spell to clear a path indirectly. 

You raise your wand. "Fiel fresa fusila fuego!"

A magical flame whooshes out of your wand, sending golden sparks shooting.

The flame doesn't harm the woodlice, but it heats the air, and dries it. The woodlice have no option but to retreat: without moisture they can't absorb oxygen, they would suffocate.

This leaves a path.

"Wait!" says Snako. "I... I can't go any further."

"What's wrong?"

"It's the woodlice. I have had a terrible fear of them ever since I accidentally ate one thinking it was a small nut. The feeling of its little legs wriggling in my stomach is something that has haunted me ever since. I can't... I just can't go on."

"Listen Snako, it's ok. I'll keep going but if you're too afraid you are no good to me down here anyway. You should turn back and tell Slumblebore what we have found down here. Tell him that I wasn't afraid and decided to carry on"

"Yes, yes... I will Arthur. Slumblebore needs to know," says Snako in relief. "I'll go and tell him."

Snako turns and hot-foots it back the way you came. 

As his hurried footsteps fade into the distant darkness, you breathe deeply and plunge forwards past the woodlouse army who are retreating into the still moist cracks in the stone.

After walking further down the dank, chilly passage you come to a door made of iron bars.

Just beyond you can hear a faint murmur of voices.

This is it: the heart of the dungeon. Whoever or whatever has been setting these traps for you and Snako must be here, at the bottom of it all.
choice_1_text: You push open the door and go inside.
title: The heart of the dungeon

content:
"Openus Sesamus!" you cry, flourishing your wand.

The door starts to shine with a magical golden glow.

You almost can't believe it but it looks like you have guessed the password correctly.
choice_1_text: It's working! Kensley breathes.
title: It's working!

content:
Tweetle beetle bottle battle!" you cry as you round the corner with Daniel just behind you.

Aiming your wand at the beetles... nothing happens.

"What are you trying to do?" shouts Daniel.

"I don't know! I just thought that might work!"

"That's not even magic that's just gibberish!"

"But magic is just gibberish to me, my thesis was that if..."

But you never get the chance to tell Daniel what your thesis was. Three pops are followed by three blasts of superheated acid. 

You try to duck out of the way but you are just a fraction too slow. One splurge of acid grazes your forehead and you fall to the ground, overcome.

Daniel hits the ground heavily beside you.

The last thing you see before you lose consciousness is the three giant bombardier beetles doing what appears to be a celebratory dance at the far end of the corridor.
choice_1_text: You remain unconscious for several hours
title: Tweetle Beetle Bottle Battle

content:
You and Aaron join the train of students from Lionpaw house. All the first years are chattering to each other, excited to visit their house tower for the first time.

Your route twists and turns, down passageways and corridors, through archways and cloisters. At times you pass by stained glass windows that stretch far up to the high ceiling and coloured light streams through the passageway. At other times the stone lined walls are dark and low with just the occasional torch flickering from the wall to illuminate your passage.

At last the line of Lionpaw students arrives at an archway framed in brilliant blue and gleaming gold.

"Well Lionpaws!" shouts out an older girl at the front of the line. "We have arrived at Lionpaw House tower! First years, this will be your home for the next 6 years - remember that only Lionpaws can pass this archway, so if you have any friends in other houses..." there are boos and laughter from the children at this remark "...you will have to _fraternize_ elsewhere! Into the Lion's den everyone!"

With that she turns and leads you all inside. 

You realise that the stone archway is carved in the shape of a lion's open mouth, with sharp stone fangs hanging down like stalagmites. 

When you pass through the archway you can't help but stop and stare, your mouth hanging open almost as wide as the lion's jaws you have just passed through.

You are confronted by a large bright circular space. Dangling from the ceiling far above are golden globes enchanted with a magico-flourescent light that illuminates a patterned marble floor. As you enter the room a handful of spell-bound goat-sized magical snails swivel their eyes stalks in your direction - doomed to forever slither the marble flagstones, the snails buff them to a gleaming brightness as they go. Scattered around are luxurious sofas, comfy armchairs and expensive rugs. 

Doorways leading to staircases are spaced at regular intervals around this enormous room. Above each doorway is a little sign and you read some of them:

"Bedrooms. Snack store. Swimming Pool. Virtual reality gaming room. Sauna. Infinity Pools. Steam Room...." you look at Aaron. "Did you know about this? This place is amazing!"

Alex Bleazely, Aaron's older brother hears you: "Listen Arthur, if Hogsnorts is going to attract the best talent and compete with the top international universities like Yale, Cambridge, Dorkstrang and Hull we need the best facilities. Right, I'm going to change into my swimming trunks - last one in the Jacuzzi is an eggy drifter!"

Alex and Robert Bleezely dash off, followed by two or three other Lionpaw students, whooping and hollering.

"Let's go and find our bedrooms Arthur," says Aaron.

You go up the staircase marked "Bedrooms" and when you reach the next floor you see two more doorways, one with a sign saying "Arthur" above it and another with an "Aaron" sign. By some magical warping of space the inside of the Lionpaw House tower must be much bigger than the outside.

You push open the door to your bedroom.

A softly carpeted corridor opens onto a cozy little living room. Another door leads to a spacious bathroom containing a large bathtub with four carved iron lion feet at each corner. Finally your bedroom itself, in the centre of which is a giant four-poster bed, festooned with blue and gold drapes. On the pillow is a cuddly little toy lion and a small mint chocolate. A window in your bedrooms looks out over the Hogsnorts school grounds far below where the sun is sinking below the horizon.

You take off your shoes and jump backwards onto the bed. I could be happy here you think to yourself as you crunch up the mint chocolate - already it feels like home. With a smile on your face you fall fast asleep.
choice_1_text: Sleep deeply then wake up refreshed in the morning.
title: The Lionpaw House Tower

content:
"Door lock undone, unlock door done!" you cry, flourishing your wand.

The door starts to shine with a magical golden glow.

"It's working!" you think to yourself, "I can't believe it worked!".
choice_1_text: "Amazing! How did you know that was the password?" Aaron cries out.
title: It's working!

content:
You and Daniel start pushing at the spider web with your hands.

It is amazingly strong and also _sticky_. With every push you get more and more enmeshed in the web and it becomes harder and harder to unstick yourself.

"Arthur", cries Daniel, "I'm stuck!"

You turn to the side and see that somehow Daniel has got himself totally tangled up in the web - he is hanging upside down with spider webs curled round his ankles and his hair brushing the floor.

"Don't worry Daniel, let's see if we can figure out a way to free ourselves!" you reply but as you try to move over towards Daniel you feel thick ropes of spider web curl around your legs and lift you up into the air. In an instant you are as helpless as he is.

You feel your panic rising as you struggle. Who is going to help you now? No-one even knows that you are here except perhaps Slumblebore.

"Watch out Arthur, look! Spiders! Millions of spiders!"

Daniel is right. Crawling out of the cracks of the walls, floor and ceiling is a host of spiders. They scurry along the webs heading for you and Daniel. In a sudden insight you realise that these spiders have made the webs themselves, working as a one enormous team to add strand after strand of spider silk until they had created these rope-thick cobwebs. So many spiders working as one! You are amazed to see such well coordinated behaviour, so rare in most spider species. Has a new species evolved in the dungeon? you wonder.

Then all thoughts flee from your mind as the wave of spiders reach you. They stop inches away.

One lone spider - no bigger than the rest - scuttles out of the pack, delicately steps onto your robes then up to your neck. You see a flash of tiny fangs then you fade into unconsciousness.
choice_1_text: As the sleeping poison takes effect your last thought is - did that spider wink just at me?
title: The dark web

content:
"Wobble wibble webby wane," you chant, pointing your wand at the web.

Nothing happens.

The spider web doesn't budge an inch.

"That doesn't _sound_ like a proper spell Arthur," says Daniel. "Did you just make it up yourself."

"Err, yes," you reply feeling a little silly. "I thought it was worth a try."
choice_1_text: You take a deep breath and consider your next move.
title: A silly spell

content:
You choose Offensive Magic with Professor Comicus Jape.

You find the classroom after only a few wrong turns, and take a seat next to Snako. You see a boy called Aaron Bleezely from Lionpaw class looking at you with a frown in his face. Stupid Lionpaws, you think to yourself, and sneer at him supersiliously.

"Now then children!" Professor Jape calls out at the front of the class. "Now then, now then! It's so lovely to meet you all."

Professor Jape is wearing a black cape with a red velvet lining and has a very pale almost white face. He smiles at the class warmly and gives a little wink.

"Today we are going to learn some offensive magic. Now as you probably know offensive magic can be extremely dangerous. But that's not to say we can't have a bit of a laugh and a giggle as we go along eh? Eh children? Eh?"

Professor Jape makes a loud high pitched giggling noise. Some of the other children laugh back nervously.

"In fact I always like to break the ice with my new children with a joke. Hands up if you want to hear one of my jokes children."
choice_1_text: You put your hand up - you could do with a laugh.
choice_2_text: You keep your hand down - this is a waste of time and you want to learn spells.
title: Professor Jape

content:
You and Aaron head to the main hall where you had dinner on the first night. There on the wall are pinned the lesson timetables for the different year groups. Lots of children clamour round trying to see where to go next.

"Here we are," you say. "What lesson shall we go to?"

You look down the list and choose...
choice_1_text: Offensive magic, with Professor Comicus Jape.
choice_2_text: Defence against the dark arts, with Professor Madame Blatavsky.
title: Lesson time
choice_3_text: Care of magical creatures, with Professor Eric Knid.
choice_4_text: You decide to call it a day and head back to the House Tower

content:
As the other Ravenwing students file off into the corridor on their way to Ravenwing House tower you and Daniel quietly tip-toe away to the side. After two or three turns of the passageway the noise of the other students has faded to nothing.

"Now where?" asks Daniel, a tremor of fear and excitement in his voice.

You look around trying to get your bearings. You realise that the school is absolutely huge. There must be hundreds of corridors, archways, passageways and staircases. How will you even find the way to the dungeons?

Just then you notice five spiders walking along the floor, lined up one after the other. What are those curious little creatures up to? you think, and start to follow them along the corridor.

They turn left, right, right again, then left before disappearing under a crack in the doorway.

You look up. Above the door is a sign scrawled in thick black letters: DUNGEONS.

"This is it!" you whisper to Daniel, afraid to speak too loud in the silence. You reach out to turn the great brass doorknob and open the door. But it doesn't budge, and as you pull on the doorknob the edge of the door glows golden.

"Look!" says Daniel to you quietly, "The door is enchanted with an enchantment of locking. We'll never open it if we don't know the magic password. We need to figure out a way to get the password if we are going to get inside."

At that moment you hear lots of footsteps coming your way from around a corner. It must be a group of students on their way to their house tower! Before you have time to hide, they turn the corner and spot you.

"Arthur and Daniel isn't it? What are you two doing there, exploring the castle already? Come on back into line!" To your surprise you are addressed by one of the older Ravenwing students. You must have somehow taken a hidden shortcut when following the spiders.
choice_1_text: You head back into the line and head off into the passageway with the rest of the students. You glance back thoughtfully at the dungeon door as you walk away: you'll figure it out someday soon.
title: The dungeon door

content:
The clock strikes one... two... three.

The golden glow shining all around you gets stronger and stronger and soon you have to shut your eyes to the blinding golden light.

After a momentary sensation of vertigo, as if you have all of a sudden _fallen_, you sense that the golden light is fading away.

Opening your eyes you find you are at the bottom of a great stone well, with a circle of light far above. You realise that you have magically transported back to Percy the Picking Pigeon's hole in the Hogsnort's Great Hall, just as Slumblebore said you would. Somehow you know that you have also travelled back in time to before, when you had just arrived at the school. You are that Arthur once again in Percy's hole, but this time you can make a new choice.

"Well Arthur," says a voice directly to your brain. "What will you choose, coo coo." It is Percy the giant pigeon and you see again his giant yellow eyes staring at you.

This time you know you will make a good choice...
choice_1_text: I want to be in Lionpaw House, the home of the brave, you think hard to yourself.
choice_2_text: For me it is Ravenwing House, you think, I want to learn and explore.
title: Another chance
choice_3_text: Snakefang House for me, I want to rise to the top and be the best, you say in your mind.
choice_4_text: I want to be in Hedgehog House please, you think, I want to have a nice time and stay out of trouble.

content:
"Vamos varita vencer vistosamente!" you exclaim as dramatically as you can manage.

A flickering golden light slowly extends from the top of your wand until it is about a metre long. You swing the "light sword" around and it makes a satisfying swishing zooming sound. You feel slightly terrified at the thought of all the damage you could do with this sabre made of light.

You take a tentative swipe at the nearest strand of spider silk. Despite it being as thick as a steel cable and twice as tough, the light sword slices through it with no effort at all and the spider web flops to the floor. 

You steadily walk forwards, cutting through the spider web with your magical golden light sword, feeling the magic from the wand course through your body. You feel you are getting the hang of this magic thing!

Soon the spider web has gone. You and Kensley race down the passageway and skid around a corner...
choice_1_text: You skid round the corner...
title: Cut through the web

content:
Looking around you, you can see that you are at the junction of a number of stone corridors.

One passageway has a sign above it saying "Slumblebore's office this way".

Another one appears to lead downwards with a gentle slope.

A spiral staircase climbs up from another doorway. A little sign with an arrow reads: "Your heart's desire's desire."

The new moon shines in from a tall narrow window.

You remember that the corridor to your left goes back to your house tower.

"Where shall we go now Arthur?" asks Snako.
choice_1_text: "Let's see if we can sneak a look at Slumblebore's office! He must have loads of cool stuff hidden away in there."
choice_2_text: "Let's try and find the dungeon. I want to know what is going on down there that has Slumblebore so worried."
title: Night school
choice_3_text: "I'm feeling tired. Let's go back to the house tower and get some sleep."
choice_4_text: "What do you think 'Your heart's desire's desire' means?" you ask. "Let's go up that staircase and have a look."

content:
You enter the passageway sloping downwards and after many twists and turns in the passageway you are hopelessly lost.

You notice a charming little spider running around a corner ahead of you. Curiously it then comes back round the corner, looks at you and waits, then lifts up a spindly leg and points.

"Arthur" says Kensley, "I think that charming little little spider wants us to follow him."

"I'm not sure if we should really be doing this..." you say. "But Let's see where it goes."

You follow the spider as it turns this way then that and are delighted to finally arrive at what must surely be the entrance to the dungeon.

A huge wooden door, banded with iron and patterned with silver swirls, stands within a stone archway. Either side of the door two antique sets of armour are positioned upright as if on guard. 

The spider you were following scurries through the keyhole of the door and disappears.

Above the door there is a sign written in some archaic font, which reads: "DUNGEON".

"Arthur!" Kensley exclaims, "I think this may be the door to the dungeon!"

"You may be onto something Kensley", you reply. "But don't get carried away _just_ yet."

You try the doorknob... but it doesn't budge. 

"There's a magical enchantment of locking on the door!" says Kensley. "We will need to cast a counter spell if we are to get through."

As you lift up your wand, you rack your brains to try to think of a spell that might work.
choice_1_text: Openus Sesamus! you cry.
choice_2_text: Door lock undone, unlock door done! you say
title: The dungeon door
choice_3_text: Ziggidy zaggady zock unlock! you chant
choice_4_text: "Watermelon!" you shout
choice-5-text: It's no use, you can't remember any unlocking spells, you will have to go back to your dormitory to sleep and try to learn one tomorrow.

content:
You find yourself face to face with a trio of bombardier beetles, who seem to be guarding the way. 

"Look how large these three fine specimens are!" says Daniel. "I wonder how they will react to a human presence?"

You find out immediately: as one of them makes an angry chittering sound. Even though you don't understand the beetle exactly, you are pretty sure he or she or it doesn't like you.

The three beetles turn around in the corridor to face away from you. 

"How curious, they seem to be retreating" remarks Daniel with a puzzled look.

Suddenly there is a loud popping sound and an aqueous solution of hydroquinones and hydrogen peroxides shoots out of the beetles' posterior regions. 

"Duck!" you cry, and you and Daniel throw yourself to one side. The liquid misses you by inches. The stone flagstone bubbles and fizzes where the liquid struck it.

You both pick yourself up off the floor and scramble back round the corner for safety.

"That was too close," you say. "We need to find a way to immobilise those beetles, or distract them somehow."

You think hard, there must be a spell that you can use that would incapacitate those three remarkable creatures, preferably without harming them so they can be studied later.

After a moment, with a determined spring in your step, you decide. You leap out from your hiding place, your wand at the ready.
choice_1_text: Yelling "Tweetle beetle bottle battle!"
choice_2_text: Shouting "Paraguas pronto!"
title: Beetle battle
choice_3_text: Screaming "Die beetles, die."
choice_4_text: Crying "Somnolencia salchicha sabrosa!"
choice-5-text: This is all getting a bit hairy, you decide that the best course of action will be to retreat and come back tomorrow, having learnt some anti-beetle spells.

content:
With a groan you open your eyes.

Looking around you you appear to be in the Hogsnorts School hospital. You see Snako lying next to you on an identical bed, also groaning. Various medical instruments hang on the walls: stethoscopes, ear trumpets, bone-saws, syringes and thaumometers.

How did I get here? you wonder. Then it comes back to you and you shudder: the dungeon. 

Something bad is definitely going on down there. Now even more than before you realise that you _have_ to find out whatever it is that is happening down there and put a stop to it. Or somehow claim its power for yourself. It is up to you - and for next time you know at least one choice that you should not make again...

"Hello Arther and Snako. I see you have returned to the conscious realm." Madame Blavatsky, the Professor of Defence Against Dark Magic walks into the room.

"Wssrrflbittit?" you mumble.

"Yes you had quite a shock back there I'm sure. When Slumblebore found you, you were both completely unconscious. But don't worry you will make a full recovery - the antiodarkotics I gave you will flush all the bad magic out shortly."

"Thank you" you manage to say.

"But the most important thing is that you get some rest. I'm going to cast a sleeping spell on you now, timed so that you will wake up tomorrow morning at 7am. When you are sleeping soundly I will teleport you to your own bedrooms in your House Tower."

As she chants the magic words "_somnolencia salchicha sabrosa_" you try to speak but you can't stop yourself drifting away.

What is in the dungeon? you desperately want to ask. Your lips form the word "Wha...?"...
choice_1_text: Then you drift off into a deep healing sleep.
title: A speedy recovery

content:
With an uncharacteristic flash of inspiration, you remember that woodlice are one of the few creatures that are completely immune to magic of any kind... but! They detest dryness and heat. Ergo you can cast a heat spell to clear a path indirectly. Brilliant!

You raise your wand. "Fiel fresa fusila fuego!"

A magical flame whooshes out of your wand, sending golden sparks shooting.

The flame doesn't harm the woodlice, but it heats the air, and dries it. The woodlice have no option but to retreat: without moisture they can't absorb oxygen, they would suffocate.

This leaves open a path.

"Wait!" says Kensley. "I... I can't go on."

"What's wrong? Why not?"

"It's the woodlice. I have had a terrible fear of them ever since one accidentally rolled into my cake mixture when I was a child. It got baked into a scone and I ate it by mistake. I can still feel the horrible crunch when I bit through its carapace, and the hideous tickle when I swallowed its roasted legs. I can't... I just can't get any closer to them."

"Listen Kensley, don't worry," you take a deep breath. "I'll keep going by myself, on my own. You get Slumblebore and tell him what is going on down here. And if should... if I should... die down here, tell him that I would like to be buried outside my lovely little Hogger Hole next to the potatoes."

"Yes, yes... I will Arthur. I'll get Slumblebore and we will bury you in the potato patch together," says Kensley with a little sniffle.

Kensley turns and walks quickly back up the passageway. As she walks you notice that she has put her hand in her pocket and is fiddling with something which then drops out of her pocket and hits the stone flagstones with a faint chink. Kensley doesn't notice and walks on, but the _thing_ bounces and then rolls down the corridor towards you, stopping at your feet.

You bend down and pick it up. It is a ring of pure gold.

How curious, you think.

Even more curious, you can just make out some tiny writing engraved on the surface of the ring, which says:

::: text-poem
_One Ring to trick them all,  
One Ring to cloud you,  
One Ring to fool them all,  
In ghostly darkness shroud you._
:::

But there is no time to worry about mysterious rings: you breathe deeply and plunge forwards past the woodlouse army who are delving into the still moist cracks in the stone.

After walking further down the dank, chilly passage you come to a door made of iron bars.

Just beyond you can hear a faint murmur of voices.

This is it: the heart of the dungeon. Whoever or whatever has been setting these traps for you and Kensley must be here, at the bottom of it all.
choice_1_text: You push open the door and go inside.
title: The heart of the dungeon

content:
"I will do it, though I do not know how," you say. 

"My dear Arthur! Students really are amazing creatures. You can learn all that there is to know about their ways in a day and yet after a hundred years they can still surprise you." Slumblebore regards you with twinkling eyes and chuckles.

"As to the how: first you must deactivate the locking spell on the dungeon door with the magic password: watermelon."

"Watermelon?" you repeat.

"Yes: watermelon. I chose this password because it is my favourite fruit. The juicy red flesh, so tasty!... the visual contrast with the green outer skin.... the crunchy black pips - delicious!"

Slumblebore stares into the distance for a few moments then snaps out of his reverie.

"Where was I? Yes: watermelon. Then you must descend the staircase that leads down into the very depths of the school. In the past students would be imprisoned in the dungeons for misbehaviour. Now they are mainly used to store broken chairs and Christmas decorations. But we go down there so infrequently there is no telling what evil is brewing in some dark corner."

"I advise you to keep your wand at the ready and your wits sharp Arthur. And remember all the lessons, all the spells, the teachers have taught you. You will be put to the test and I do not know how it will turn out."

"Sir," you ask. "What do you _think_ is down there?"

"Long have I studied this question, seeking knowledge in ancient scrolls and consulting with the wisest of the wise. Not a sausage. All I can say is that in the dead of night when I listen hard at the dungeon door I can sometimes hear a faint murmuring noise... like the ghosts of a thousand lost souls groaning at their fate. Either that or it's the hot water system."
choice_1_text: Gathering your courage you head out of the office back to the midnight Hogsnorts corridors.
title: What must I do?

content:
"Wobble wibble webby wane," you chant, pointing your wand at the web.

Nothing happens.

The spider web doesn't budge an inch.

"That doesn't _sound_ like a proper spell Arthur," says Snako. "Did you just make it up yourself."

"Err, yes," you reply feeling a little silly. "I thought it was worth a try."
choice_1_text: You take a deep breath and consider your next move.
title: A silly spell

content:
You wake up and for a moment you can't remember where you are. Then slowly it comes back to you: you are in your own underground home set into the side of a hill which you have reached by ascending an enchanted teleportation tower in Hogsnorts School of Magic. You are in the best house - Hedgehog House - and you have a new best friend - Kensley Potato.

You sigh with happiness. Yes, life is good right now. 

But that reminds you: Kensley! She had her own Hogger-hole next door. You throw on your clothes as quickly as you can and dash down your tunnel to find her.

Just as you are running out of your door, you see Kensley dashing out of her door to come and find you. 

"Arthur!" she says, "isn't this place so nice? I've got my own house in the hillside with polished chairs and pegs and everything!"

"But listen," she continues, not giving you the chance to reply. "Why don't we stay here for the day instead of going for lessons? I'm sure no-one would notice if we weren't there. And I want to have a look around here first."
choice_1_text: "I'm not sure Kensley," you reply. "I don't want to get into trouble. And I want to learn some spells too."
choice_2_text: "Yes ok," you say. "And I'm sure you're right, no-one will notice if we don't turn up ."
title: The wake up call

content:
"I'm not sure I really fit in with my house," you say.

"Not the right house, eh?" repeats Slumblebore. "Well it wouldn't be the first time it has happened. Percy can pigeon hole people a bit too quickly at times - he is getting old now and sometimes I think his heart isn't really in it any more. Despite the fact that we feed him well and he gets to sing a song every year."

"Yes," you say, "I think it just all happened too quickly when I arrived at the school and I didn't really know what it is was going to be _like_ in Hedgehog House."

"Hmmm," ponders Slumblebore. "With a bit more time you may come to like it, don't you think? You know that after Percy the Picking Pigeon has chosen your house you can't change it."

"No I'm never going to like it sir," you reply blinking back tears. "I don't even like hedgehogs. I just pretended to, to fit in. I'll just be miserable my entire life."

"Well... in that case there is something I can do. I said that you can't change your house _after_ you have chosen it but luckily I am something of an expert in temporal magic - the magic of time. I can send you back in time to _before_ you have chosen your house and you can choose all over again. How about that Arthur?"

You nod in reply. "Yes thank you sir."

"Well then, just step into this clock over here..." Slumblebore points to a large grandfather clock standing against the wall. The clock face is a little higher than your head and the main body of the clock has a small door, with a space behind that you can squeeze into. 

"I'm going to set the time to after dinner on the first night..."

You can see Slumblebore's feet and flowing robes as he fiddles with the clock face above you. 

"When the clock strikes three you will travel back in time, and if I have got my calculations right, you will also travel sideways in space to arrive in the great hall at just the right time. Remember to come and see me again in my office later on. Or do I mean earlier on? The magic is starting soon now, good luck!"

You can feel a tingling sensation as the magic travelling clock starts to power up. A faint sparkly golden glow feels the space that you are crouched in. You hear the clock strike one, two...
choice_1_text: Here goes, back in time to a new house and a new start at Hogsnorts!
choice_2_text: Stop, I've changed my mind! you shout and leap out of the clock. "I don't want to change houses or go back in time!"
title: Time for a change

content:
"Yes there is something I need to talk to you about Arthur, something very important," says Slumblebore. 

"Ever since the end of the last school term I have sensed an evil presence in the school. An evil presence that is growing stronger by the day. All that I have been able to determine is that it is coming from the school dungeons. But _what_ it is and _where_ exactly it is down there I do not know. Whatever it is, is beyond my power."

Slumblebore looks at you directly, his bushy eyebrows waggling. 

"This is where you come in Arthur. I need you to investigate what is going on in the dungeon. And deal with it."

"You want me to go to the dungeon!" you ask, amazed. "But you said at the school dinner that the dungeon was forbidden and no children were to go anywhere near!"

"Yes but Arthur don't you see? I can't just go around encouraging all the children to go down into the dungeons. There would be a stampede! And imagine if anything happened to them? Their parents would take Hogsnorts School to court, the fines could be crippling! No far better if you could just handle this quietly. And don't tell anyone that I told you to go down there."

"But I don't know hardly any magic!" you exclaim, "I've only just started magic school!"

"I agree you should learn one or two spells before you venture down. Pay attention to your teachers! What they teach you could save your life."

"But why me sir? Why not ask one of the older children to do it? Why don't _you_ do it?"

"There is one more thing I haven't told you Arthur. In the summer holidays I discovered an ancient prophecy concerning the school. It was written on a scroll that was so old that as soon as I touched it it turned to dust. It said: 

::: text-poem
'_When darkness falls across your school. 
And evil threatens to rise and rule,  
When monsters lurk around school ground. 
The boy called Arthur must be found._'
:::

"Your coming has been foretold. If the prophecy is correct, only you can save us."

"And if you do this thing Arthur," Slumblebore adds, "I will personally award one million points for Snakefang House."
choice_1_text: "What must I do?" you ask, with a determined look in your eye.
choice_2_text: "This is totally crazy," you exclaim. "You want me to fight an evil monster all on my own just because of some old poem? I'm just a kid!" As you leave the office Slumblebore calls after you: "I'll be here waiting for you Arthur, when you find your courage."
title: The prophecy

content:
As you wake, for a moment you are confused where you are. You can hear the sound of birds chirping through an open window and there is a faint woody aroma in the air. 

Then, with a warm glow, you remember. You are in Ravenwing House Tower, and your new home-away-from-home is in the inside of a giant magical tree. As well as having the largest library in the history of the world (past and future), it also has a lovely en-suite bedroom just for you with a cosy living room attached. You sigh happily - the life of a wizard is not bad at all.

Then you remember that your new best friend Daniel Colliers-Wood also has a bedroom next door, so you throw your clothes on and dash out to find him. 

As you run out of your room into the wooden corridor you see Daniel dashing along the corridor towards you. 

"Arthur this tower is amazing! There's so much to see. Let's explore the Ravenwing tower today and skip our lessons."
choice_1_text: "I'm not sure Daniel," you say. "I really want to learn some magic spells..."
choice_2_text: "Great idea," you reply. "We can always catch up on school work tomorrow!"
title: The wake up call

content:
Looking around you, you can see that you are at the junction of a number of stone corridors.

One passageway has a sign above it saying "Slumblebore's office this way".

Another one appears to lead downwards with a gentle slope.

A spiral staircase climbs up from another doorway. A little sign with an arrow reads: "Your heart's desire's desire."

The new moon shines in from a tall narrow window.

You remember that the corridor to your left goes back to your house tower.

"Where shall we go now Arthur?" asks Kensley.
choice_1_text: Let's see if we can take a look at Slumblebore's office - he must surely be asleep at this time.
choice_2_text: Let's try and find the dungeon. What can it be that has even Slumblebore worried?
title: Night school
choice_3_text: I'm feeling tired. Let's go back to the house tower and get some sleep.
choice_4_text: What do you think 'Your heart's desire's desire' means? you ask. "Let's go up that staircase and have a look."

content:
As the other Lionpaw students file off into the corridor on their way to Lionpaw House tower you and Aaron quietly slip away to the side. After two or three turns of the passageway the noise of the other students has faded to nothing.

"Now where?" asks Aaron.

You look around trying to get your bearings. You realise that the school is absolutely huge. There must be hundreds of corridors, archways, passageways and staircases. How will you even find the way to the dungeons?

Just then you notice five spiders walking along the floor, lined up one after the other. How odd, you think and start to follow them along the corridor.

They turn left, right, right again, then left before disappearing under a crack in the doorway.

You look up. Above the door is a sign scrawled in thick black letters: DUNGEONS.

"We've made it," you whisper to Aaron, afraid to speak too loud in the silence. You reach out to turn the great brass doorknob and open the door. But it doesn't budge, and as you pull on the doorknob the edge of the door glows golden.

"Look!" says Aaron to you quietly, "the door is enchanted. We'll never open it if we don't know the magic password."

At that moment you hear lots of footsteps coming your way from around a corner. It must be a group of students on their way to their house tower! Before you have time to hide, they turn the corner and spot you.

"Arthur and Aaron isn't it? What are you doing there? Come on get back into line!" To your surprise you are addressed by one of the older Lionpaw students. You must have somehow taken a hidden shortcut when following the spiders.
choice_1_text: You slink back into the line and head off into the passageway with the rest of the students. You glance back at the dungeon door as you walk away and whisper over your shoulder: "We'll be back!"
title: The dungeon door

content:
Professor Eric Knid's classroom is on the ground floor, in a wing of Hogsnorts castle that sticks out a little from the main building. The windows look onto vegetable gardens on one side and some overgrown brambles on the other.

You walk into the class with Snako and sit down. For this lesson Snakefang House first years have combined with Hedgehog House first years. Kensley Potato - a first year Hogger - sits down on your other side and starts fiddling with her pencil case. 

Professor Knid stands at the front patiently while the children settle. His long arms and legs poke out of his wizard's gown. A strange shimmery cloak dangles from his shoulders. Dressed all in black he looks rather like an overgrown spider.

When there is silence he raises his hands. His odd looking cloak flutters around him while he speaks:

"Today you will learn about the care of magical creatures.

"But before we do that let me take this opportunity to remind you of Slumblebore's warning at the house sorting dinner." Professor Knid looks out at the class with a piercing gaze and it appears to you that his eyes are focused directly on you.

"No-one must go into the dungeons this term. There is something mysterious and very probably dangerous down there this term, and no-one is allowed to interrupt. Is that clear?"

Nods all round from the class. You exchange raised eyebrows with Snako. What could be going on down there? And why was Professor Knid staring straight at you?

"Right!" Knid claps his hands."Can anyone tell me the most common type of magical creature?"

"Unicorns?" shouts out one boy.

"Witches cats!" shouts a girl at the back. 

"Flying monkeys!" shouts someone else. 

"These are all good answers. But not correct. The most common type of magical creature is the insect, or, more generally: the arthropod. Spiders, snails, flies, ants, beetles, woodlice, these are all infinitely more common than the unicorn. And many of them have been enchanted by a magician or witch at some point in the past making them effectively immortal until trodden on. 

"For example, look closely at my cloak children." Eric Knid walks up and down the class so the children can see better.

You realise that the professor's cloak is not merely shimmering, it is _moving_. It seems to be made up of lots of tiny moving _things_. Then you realise what they are and your eyes widen in hideous fascination.

Eric Knid's cloak is made up of thousands upon thousands of flies, each fly grasping the flies next to it with their tiny hairy legs. As they flutter their wings or move their black and iridescent green bodies, the cloak appears to undulate as if in a breeze. 

To you and the rest of the class it seems revolting, but Professor Knid is oblivious.

"Until you look closely my cloak is just an ordinary magician's cape. But it is actually made up of thousands of enchanted and specially trained flies. And each one can fly off at my command to do my bidding - to deliver a message perhaps, or sit on someone's dinner, or to distract a powerful wizard in the act of casting a spell.

"Yes the insect world is a vast and overlooked wonder and in this lesson I am going to teach you about a tiny portion of it.

"But before we learn any magic, does anyone doubt me that the arthropods - the insects - are the true marvels of the animal world?"

Professor Knid looks round expectantly, his eyebrows raised.
choice_1_text: You don't like insects that much. You raise your hand to ask what makes them better than other animals.
choice_2_text: You don't say anything. Clearly Professor Knid had got a bugbear about insects and he is just itching to waste the whole lesson talking about them. You would rather learn some magic.
title: Professor Eric Knid

content:
"Die beetles, die!" you cry, running towards the three giant bombardier beetles. 

In your battle rage you forget all about magic and your wand, you just want to reach the beetles and grapple them with your bare hands, mano a beetlo.

"Yaaaah!" you cry, closing the distance fast...

...but not fast enough. The three beetles swiftly raise up their bottoms, and shoot out three streams of superheated acid, accompanied by three loud popping sounds.

One stream misses your head by inches, another strikes the wall beside you, the third the floor in front. 

"Hahahaha, you'll never get me for I dance the dance of..."

But you never get the chance to tell them exactly what dance it is you are dancing because at that moment your foot slips on the pool of acid on the floor and slides out from underneath you. You fly through the air very briefly before slamming into the floor, bumping your head hard enough to knock you out cold.
choice_1_text: You remain unconscious for an indeterminate length of time
title: Battle rage

content:
"Wobble wibble webby wane," you chant, pointing your wand at the web.

Nothing happens.

The spider web doesn't budge an inch.

"That doesn't _sound_ like a real spell Arthur," says Kensley. "Did you just make it up?"

"Err, yes," you reply feeling a little silly. "I thought it was worth a try."
choice_1_text: You take a deep breath and consider your next move.
title: A silly spell

content:
You remember that woodlice are one of the few creatures that are completely immune to magic of any kind, and decide to cast a heat spell to clear a path indirectly.

You raise your wand. "Fiel fresa fusila fuego!"

A magical flame whooshes out of your wand, sending golden sparks shooting.

The flame doesn't harm the woodlice, but it heats the air, and dries it. The woodlice have no option but to retreat: without moisture they can't absorb oxygen, they would suffocate.

This leaves a path.

You breathe deeply and plunge forwards past the woodlouse army who are retreating into the still moist cracks in the stone.

After walking further down the dank, chilly passage you and Daniel come to a door made of iron bars.

Just beyond you can hear a faint murmur of voices.

This is it: the heart of the dungeon. Whoever or whatever has been setting these traps for you and Daniel must be here, at the bottom of it all.
choice_1_text: You push open the door and go inside.
title: The heart of the dungeon

content:
You leap out of the clock just in time, you could already feel the magic sucking you down.

Breathing hard you look back at the clock face and see the hands of the clock spinning madly backwards.

"You have changed your mind about changing your mind have you?" Slumblebore observes, his bushy eyebrows waggling. "Well you can come and see me at any time and change your mind again if you want."

"I... I... I think I don't want to leave Ravenwing just yet," you stammer. You are not quite sure why you changed your mind at the last minute, but it just didn't feel... right.

"Well as you are not going anywhere just yet, let's get talking about the problem we have right now," says Slumblebore. "I'm talking of course about what we are going to do about the evil presence in the school dungeon. I fear it is something that may threaten the very existence of Hogsnorts."
choice_1_text: You sit down in a chair next to Slumblebore's desk and prick up your ears.
title: Just in time

content:
You and Snako start pushing at the spider web with your hands.

It is amazingly strong and also _sticky_. When you push a strand it becomes harder and harder to unstick your hands.

"Arthur", cries Snako, "I'm stuck!"

You turn to the side and see that somehow Snako has got himself totally tangled up in the web - he is hanging upside down with spider webs curled round his ankles and his hair brushing the floor.

"Hang in there Snako, I'm going to see if I can get through!" you reply but as you try to move over towards Snako you feel thick ropes of spider web curl around your legs and lift you up into the air. In an instant you are as helpless as Snako.

You feel your panic rising as you struggle. Who is going to help you now? No-one even knows that you are here except perhaps Slumblebore.

"Aaargh! Look Arthur - spiders! Millions of spiders!"

Snako is right. Crawling out of the cracks of the walls, floor and ceiling is a host of spiders. They scurry along the webs heading for you and Snako. In a sudden insight you realise that these spiders have made the webs themselves, working as a one enormous team to add strand after strand of spider silk until they had created these rope-thick cobwebs. So many spiders working as one! What could they not achieve together?

Then all thoughts flee from your mind as the wave of spiders reach you. They stop inches away.

One lone spider - no bigger than the rest - scuttles out of the pack, delicately steps onto your robes then up to your neck. You see a flash of tiny fangs then you fade into unconsciousness.
choice_1_text: As the sleeping poison takes effect your last thought is - did that spider wink just at me?
title: The dark web

content:
Along with most of the other children you keep your hands down.

"You don't want to hear my jokes? Well I never!" Professor Jape looks genuinely hurt for a moment, but quickly recovers his composure.

"Perhaps you will be laughing on the other side of your face by the end of this lesson." Jape gives another high pitched giggle and you all shift on your seats uneasily. 

"Maybe," he continues, "you will enjoy this one. I need a volunteer!"

No one volunteers so Jape scans the classroom. He points at Daniel.

"You! Come forward."

Daniel walks to the front of the class looking nervous. 

Without any warning Professor Jape whips out his wand, points it at Daniel and yells: "_Vamos varita vencer vistosamente!_"

A golden light extrudes from the tip of Jape's wand. The light looks like a solid sparkly golden beam and extends for one metre then stops emerging. Jape swings his wand around and you realise that he has created a magical golden light sword! As the golden beam swipes through the air it makes satisfying swishing zoom noises.

"En guard!" snaps Jape to Daniel with a gleam in his eye before suddenly launching into a frenzied attack, swiping left and right with his light sword. In a flash he has covered the 5 metres to Daniel and he holds the light sword directly at Daniel's throat.

"Now you will die." Jape says simply.

There is dead silence in the class. Everyone is holding their breath.

Then, almost in exact unison, everyone screams and runs out of the door, except Daniel who is rooted to the spot in fear, and you because you don't want to abandon your friend.

Professor Jape lowers the light sword and gives a high pitched giggle.

"I were just joking, didn't you know that?" he said to the fleeing children. "It were just a joke!" he shouted louder at their fleeing backs.

Professor Jape sighs and says to you and Daniel: "They can't take a joke, can they? Well lessons over now I suppose. But remember: _Vamos varita vencer vistosamente_ that's a good one that is!"

You and Daniel nod and swallow, and without saying another word, flee out of the classroom.
choice_1_text: You dash back to the dining hall to find another lesson, hoping the next teacher won't be quite so bonkers.
title: Jape's spell

content:
"Openus Sesamus!" you cry, flourishing your wand.

The door starts to shine with a magical golden glow.

You almost can't believe it but it looks like you have guessed the password correctly.
choice_1_text: "It's working!" Snako cries out.
title: It's working!

content:
In front of you is a corridor. The corridor is festooned from floor to ceiling with spider web strands. These strands are so thick it is almost impossible to see along the passage.

The way is blocked.

Snako turns to you. "What are we going to do Arthur?"

You raise your wand and concentrate.
choice_1_text: Push the spider web out of the way with your hands. It's just cobwebs after all.
choice_2_text: Extending your wand arm you exclaim: "Vamos varita vencer vistosamente!"
title: Dungeon crawl
choice_3_text: "Tonto tijeras trae tiempo!" you shout out, waving your wand energetically.
choice_4_text: I wonder if this will work, you think, holding your wand aloft and chanting "Wobble wibble webby wane."
choice-5-text: This is just too stressful. You decide to head back to the house tower, learn a bit more magic and come back another day better prepared.

content:
As you shout "Watermelon!" at the top of your voice, you point your wand at the door.

You can feel your arm channel powerful magic. Magical golden lines leap from the tip of the wand. The golden lines strike the door and entwine the handle, the hinges, the iron bands that hold the door together. 

An enchantingly clear note sounds and at the same time the dungeon door swings open.

"You did it Arthur!" cries Aaron, and the two of you enter the passageway, wands at the ready. 

Stairs head downwards into the gloom, a gloom alleviated by dim flickering torches, enchanted by magic to burn forever and never go out.
choice_1_text: At the bottom of the stairs you stop and look around you.
title: Pass friend

content:
Professor Eric Knid's classroom is on the ground floor, in a wing of Hogsnorts castle that sticks out a little from the main building. The windows look onto vegetable gardens on one side and some overgrown brambles on the other.

You walk into the class with Aaron and sit down. For this lesson Lionpaw House first years have combined with Hedgehog House first years. Kensley Potato - a first year Hogger - sits down on your other side and starts fiddling with her pencil case. 

Professor Knid stands at the front patiently while the children settle. His long arms and legs poke out of his wizard's gown. A strange shimmery cloak dangles from his shoulders. Dressed all in black he looks rather like an overgrown spider.

When there is silence he raises his hands. His odd looking cloak flutters around him while he speaks:

"Today you will learn about the care of magical creatures.

"But before we do that let me take this opportunity to remind you of Slumblebore's warning at the house sorting dinner." Professor Knid looks out at the class with a piercing gaze and it appears to you that his eyes are focused directly on you.

"No-one must go into the dungeons this term. There is something mysterious and very probably dangerous down there this term, and no-one is allowed to interrupt. Is that clear?"

Nods all round from the class. You exchange raised eyebrows with Aaron. What could be going on down there? And why was Professor Knid staring straight at you?

"Right!" Knid claps his hands."Can anyone tell me the most common type of magical creature?"

"Unicorns?" shouts out one boy.

"Witches cats!" shouts a girl at the back. 

"Flying monkeys!" shouts someone else. 

"These are all good answers. But not correct. The most common type of magical creature is the insect, or, more generally: the arthropod. Spiders, snails, flies, ants, beetles, woodlice, these are all infinitely more common than the unicorn. And many of them have been enchanted by a magician or witch at some point in the past making them effectively immortal until trodden on. 

"For example, look closely at my cloak children." Eric Knid walks up and down the class so the children can see better.

You realise that the professor's cloak is not merely shimmering, it is _moving_. It seems to be made up of lots of tiny moving _things_. Then you realise what they are and your eyes widen in hideous fascination.

Eric Knid's cloak is made up of thousands upon thousands of flies, each fly grasping the flies next to it with their tiny hairy legs. As they flutter their wings or move their black and iridescent green bodies, the cloak appears to undulate as if in a breeze. 

To you and the rest of the class it seems revolting, but Professor Knid is oblivious.

"Until you look closely my cloak is just an ordinary magician's cape. But it is actually made up of thousands of enchanted and specially trained flies. And each one can fly off at my command to do my bidding - to deliver a message perhaps, or sit on someone's dinner, or to distract a powerful wizard in the act of casting a spell.

"Yes the insect world is a vast and overlooked wonder and in this lesson I am going to teach you about a tiny portion of it.

"But before we learn any magic, does anyone doubt me that the arthropods - the insects - are the true marvels of the animal world?"

Professor Knid looks round expectantly, his eyebrows raised.
choice_1_text: You don't like insects that much. You raise your hand to ask what makes them better than other animals.
choice_2_text: You don't say anything. Clearly Professor Knid had got a bugbear about insects and he is just itching to waste the whole lesson talking about them. You would rather learn some magic.
title: Professor Eric Knid

content:
Making sure that you have got all of your quills, ink bottles, spell books and sweets, you put your bag on your shoulder and leave the Great Hall to go back to the House Tower with Daniel.

Strangely enough you find you can remember the way back there easily - the path had seemed so long and winding on your first day. Perhaps it was something to do with eating the Ravenwing Egg from Percy the Picking Pigeon that has given you a homing instinct for the Tower.

When you arrive you head straight to the Ravenwing House reading room, instructing one of the enchanted parrots to fetch you some light reading from the shelves. Settling into a comfy armchair you read a couple of Kafka short stories, briefly ponder life as a giant cockroach, then turn to Daniel who is reading his own book on the armchair beside you.
choice_1_text: Let's go get some dinner, I'm absolutely famished.
choice_2_text: "I'm not hungry today, I'm just going to get some rest so I am fresh for the morning." With that you retire to your en-suite bedroom, snuggle under the duvet and quickly fall fast asleep.
title: Lessons finished for the day

content:
"I'm Arthur Otley and I want to learn some spells" you say to Professor Blavatsky.

"Ah so impatient. And yet this impatience stops you learning about yourself. I can see that you are very far from self control as yet."

The teacher stands up and raises one hand.

"But do not worry, any of you. Because we will start with a simple meditation session to help you gain control."

You groan inwardly. This sounds boring. 

"Close your eyes everyone," begins Professor Blavatsky. "Make sure you are comfortable in your seats. Now I want you to focus on your breathing. Breathe in. Breathe out. Breathe in... and breathe out.

"Feel the breath flowing into your nostrils. Concentrate on the sensation. Do you feel your nose hairs tickling? Perhaps a small bogey flapping around in your nasal passage? Just think about the breath, how it feels."

Despite yourself you feel your awareness sharpening, and you do indeed feel a small bogey in your nostril wobbling around as you breathe in and out. 

"Now I want you to think about a special number. The special number is 42. A four and then a two. Forty two. This number is not just a number it is also a place. A location. A place of calm that you can always turn to in moments of difficulty or stress. 

"This number 42 is a place within yourself, but it is a real place too that anyone can reach, if they just turn to that number... the number 42. As you turn to 42, just keep your thumb here so you know where to come back to."

Amazingly you feel a sensation as if you are floating somehow, except with your thumb stuck down in front of you. Concentrating fiercely you try with all your might to turn to 42. You float away...

...

"Did anyone manage to meditate and reach 42?" asks Madam Blavatsky. 

You definitely feel you went... somewhere. You _think_ this is what Professor Blavatsky meant.

"Any time you find yourself in need of quiet and peace, just repeat this meditation exercise and think of the number 42 and you will find a place of calm and relaxation - but keep your thumb right where you are and you will be able to turn back whenever you want."

"Class dismissed! We will meet again."
choice_1_text: As if in a daze you and the other children rise slowly to your feet and walk out of the classroom. You do feel as if maybe you know yourself a little better now.
title: Inner peace

content:
A voice, strong and commanding, emerges from the darkness. "You? The saviour, a mere stripling first year? Impossible!"  

Another voice, high pitched and chittery, answers him. "Yes Eric, this is him. He is the wand holder."

As your eyes adjust to the gloom, you can make out a figure standing in the centre of the room. A wizard - and someone you recognise. 

"Professor Knid! But what...?" you exclaim.

"Yes Professor Eric Knid at your service! Or perhaps I should say that you will be at my service... Arthur isn't it?"

"Yes my name's Arthur. Arthur Otley." A sensation of fear congeals in your throat so strong that you can barely speak. "What do you mean? And who were you talking to just now?"

"All in good time, Arthur..." with an unexpectedly swift movement Professor Knid draws his wand and shoots a spell of locking at the iron gate which... swings shut and then hits some invisible object and swings open again. There is a curious noise like a muffled cry, and then finally the clangs shut.

But there is no time to worry about the curious muffled cry - you are trapped. 

"What are you going to do?" you exclaim in a fearful high pitched squeak.

Eric Knid smiled. Even in the dark you can see the mad gleam in his eye: "Revolution!"

"Explain why Eric." That chittering voice again, appearing out of nowhere.

"Yes - why. Why?" Professor Knid takes a deep breath. "Ever since I was a young boy Arthur I have felt an affinity with insects, spiders, crabs. With the Arthropods. A dog will bite you, not so an earwig! A lion may eat you, not so a woodlouse! A human may betray you, a spider will not.

"My faithful friends growing up were slugs, ants, flies and beetles. But my friends were mercilessly crushed, poisoned, and swatted by humans.

"The final straw? Slumblebore sat on a spider - and laughed."

"I couldn't bear it. I sought out the Great Spider King Azog himself. What joy when I found him in the forbidden bushes and entered his service. Together we have been gathering supporters here in this dungeon, insects and spiders in their millions. For revenge. For a revolution. To take over the school!

"No longer will it just be Lionpaw House, Ravenwing House, Snakefang House, and Hedgehog House! We will have a new house mightier than all of them. The Order of the Arthropods! And I will be headmaster."

"But why me?" fear chills you. "I'm just a first year, I don't want any trouble."

"You are the only one who can stop us Arthur," says the mysterious high pitched voice. "But with you on our side we will be invincible!"

"Who is that?" you cry. 

"This is the Great Spider King Azog himself. And you are honoured to stand in his presence." Professor Knid explains.

"Where?" You can't see anyone other than the Professor.

"Here!"

"Where, I can't see!"

"Right here, look! Closer!"
choice_1_text: You look closer.
title: Professor Eric Knid Explains

content:
You find yourself face to face with a trio of bombardier beetles, who seem to be guarding the way. 

"My goodness!" says Kensley. "They are not friendly one bit!"

One of them makes an angry chittering sound. Even though you don't speak beetle you are pretty sure this beetle doesn't like you. 

The three beetles turn around in the corridor to face away from you. 

"Arthur do you think they're running away?" asks Kensley, tugging on your sleeve.

Suddenly there is a loud popping sound and a steam of superheated liquid shoots out of the beetles' bottoms. 

"Duck!" you cry, and you and Kensely throw yourself to one side. The liquid misses you by inches. The stone flagstone bubbles and fizzes where the liquid struck it.

You both pick yourself up off the floor and scramble back round the corner for safety.

"That was too close," you say. "We need to get past those creatures or we will never be able to get down into the dungeon."

You think hard, there must be a spell that you can use. Some spell that allows you to sneak past without them seeing you.

After a moment, a determined look in your eye, you step out from your hiding place with your wand at the ready.
choice_1_text: Yelling "Tweetle beetle bottle battle!"
choice_2_text: Shouting "Paraguas pronto!"
title: Beetle battle
choice_3_text: Screaming "Die beetles, die."
choice_4_text: Crying "Somnolencia salchicha sabrosa!"
choice-5-text: This is all getting a bit hairy, you decide that the best course of action will be to retreat and come back tomorrow, having learnt some anti-beetle spells.

content:
"Somnolencia salchicha sabrosa," you cry, brandishing your wand fiercely.

A surge of magical power flows through your body, down your arm and out through the wand. A shower of golden sparks races down the corridor raining down onto the three beetles.

Each beetle glows gold for an instant before slowly rolling onto their side and then their backs, six legs waggling gently in the air. 

"Did you kill them?" asks Snako.

"No I decided to spare their lives - they could be useful to me later. That was a sleeping spell. Look you can see their legs are still moving."

They must be dreaming some pleasant beetle dream, perhaps of cantering through a leafy carboniferous glade, as their legs make little wiggles in the air.

"Let's get past them before they wake up."

You and Snako step over the sleeping beetles, giving them a kick as you walk past. That will teach them for attacking you.

You descend a spiral staircase now and the air is getting dank and stale. It can't be long before you arrive in the dungeon. 

At the bottom of the staircase it is pitch black.

You raise your wand and the tip emits a faint golden light, just enough to see by.

You almost wish you hadn't. 

Revealed by the dim light of your wand you can see the floor and the walls are completely covered in woodlice. Millions upon millions of them cling to the damp stone slabs that make up the corridor. Millions more cover the flagstones, waving their repulsive little antennae. Others have curled up into balls and are rolling around irresponsibly.

Do woodlice even have eyes? You don't know but when you turned on your light they all seemed to turn and look at you. 

"Slithering snakebites Arthur, what are we going to do? There are too many of them to fight!"

"Don't move a muscle Snako" you say in reply. "I have an idea."
choice_1_text: You chant the spell "Fiel fresa fusila fuego."
choice_2_text: You recite the incantation "Amansa at√∫n!"
title: Woodlouse warfare
choice_3_text: You shout out "Dispara dinosaurio demente!"
choice_4_text: You decide that you will just walk forwards and crush the woodlice underfoot.
choice-5-text: You don't know the first thing about combating woodlice. It's time to retreat, regroup and learn what you can in magic lessons.

content:
"Ziggidy zaggady zock unlock!" you cry, flourishing your wand.

The door starts to shine with a magical golden glow.

"That's amazing," you think to yourself, "I think it's going to work!"
choice_1_text: "I think you managed to guess the password!" Aaron cries out.
title: It's working!

content:
"Tonto tijeras trae tiempo!" you shout out, waving your wand above your head.

To your surprise, a golden pair of magical scissors shoots out of the end of your wand and strikes the ceiling, and golden threads arch through the stone above your head.

From the golden filaments in the roof, a flutter of beautiful golden snowflakes fall. Each one has an exquisitely perfect hexagonal symmetry.

When they land on your arms and head, they give you a warm tingling sensation and then disappear with a tinkling sound, like a tiny bell.

After a few moments the golden snow fall stops and the corridor returns to its previous gloomy state.

"Wow that was amazing Arthur" says Aaron. "I don't know how you did that. But I'm afraid it doesn't help us with the spider web.
choice_1_text: You look up. Aaron's right. The spider web is still blocking your way. You will have to try something else.
title: A silly idea

content:
It takes you just an instant to decide. 

Whipping out your wand you cry "Fiel fresa fusila fuego!" and flames shoot out, bathing the dungeon in flickering light. Not while you still have a clear head and a straight wand will you let these insects take over! You are going to fight them every step of the way, starting with Azog!

Azog is too nimble to be caught so easily though and leaps out of the way.

"You will regret your choice Arthur," screams the spider king in outrage. "Insects, attack!"

From out of cracks in the walls, ceiling and floor crawl millions upon millions of arthropods: beetles, woodlice, ants, millipedes, earwigs, spiders in a great stream heading straight for you.

This time you don't hesitate. If you stay you will be surrounded and overwhelmed.

"Daniel, run!" you say as you turn and flee. 

Your heart pounding, you and Daniel run back out of the dungeon up towards the school. You have a plan.

When you reach the enchanted door that leads down into the dungeon you dash through, Daniel just behind you, and slam it shut. You can hear the enchanted locking mechanism clicking shut.

There's only one way for the insects to get past the door now - through the keyhole. You turn and wait, your wand at the ready. Daniel stands next to you, prepared.

As soon as you see the first hairy little leg poking out of the keyhole you use your wand as a flamethrower shouting "fiel fresa fusila fuego" again and again until your voice is hoarse. Daniel joins you adding his flames to yours.

The air is full of the harsh high pitched cries of dying arthropods and the sizzle of roasting chitin. But still the insects come, propelled onwards by the Great Azog's iron will.

You and Daniel are getting tired now, your arm is sore from being held up so long and you can feel your reserves of magical energy running out. You cannot hold out much longer.

For a moment the magical fire from your wand flickers and dies.

Then three things happen simultaneously: 

One: Azog, sensing his chance, launches himself through the keyhole aiming straight for your face. 

Two: Slumblebore runs round the corner to see you battling the numberless insect foe on your own.

Three: your faltering spell was a ruse. You have enough magical power for one last enchantment, but this time it won't be a fireball...

"Somnolencia salchicha sabrosa!" you cry pointing at your wand at Azog as he flies through the air towards you.

Then...

Azog, leaping through the air fangs at the ready, is unable to change direction. Just as your wand arm comes _up_ he reaches the tip of the wand, and has no time to avoid the sleep spell which blasts him right in the middle of his eight little compound eyes.

Even the great Azog cannot withstand such a concentrated blast of magic at point blank range. He is blasted backwards, fast asleep and snoring before he even hits the stone wall behind him. 

With Azog out of action the rest of the arthropod horde lose all cohesion. When Slumblebore cautiously opens the door to the dungeon they are fleeing in all directions, and will trouble the school no more. Slumblebore lets off a few more blasts of fire to encourage them on their way.

"You did it Arthur!" cries Daniel. "You saved the school - the evil has gone - and you have captured Azog alive!"

You stand still and listen carefully. Daniel is right. You cannot sense the insects any longer. The dungeons have been cleansed.

"Well done indeed Arthur," and Slumblebore, turning back to you. "I had a feeling that you were the special one. Without you I fear we would have been overrun by insects by now."

"It was Eric Knid," you say to Slumblebore. "It was Professor Knid who summoned the insect army, with Azog the spider king. He is down in the dungeon now unconscious. Azog bit him."

"Eric did you say? Well I'm not surprised. He always struck me as a bit of an odd fish. Nevermind we will pick him up in the morning and I shall give him an official reprimand. And if he does it again I will have no choice but to put him on a performance improvement plan."

"But you Arthur, what else can I give _you_ but my most heartfelt thanks." You can't suppress a broad grin. You did it! You defeated Azog and his insect army single handed, using your magical strength and cleverness!

Slumbelbore continues: "You truly are a hero Arthur, a hero of Hogsnorts School."
choice_1_text: The next day...
title: School hero

content:
You leap out of the clock just in time, you could already feel the magic sucking you down.

Breathing hard you look back at the clock face and see the hands of the clock spinning madly backwards.

"You have changed your mind about changing your mind have you?" Slumblebore observes, his bushy eyebrows raised. "Well you can come and see me at any time and change your mind again if you want."

"I... I... Thank you sir," you stammer. You are not quite sure why you changed your mind at the last minute, but it just didn't feel... right.

"Well as you are not going anywhere just yet, let's get talking about the problem we have right now," says Slumblebore. "I'm talking of course about what we are going to do about the evil presence in the school dungeon. I fear it is something that may threaten the very existence of Hogsnorts."
choice_1_text: You sit down in a chair next to Slumblebore's desk and prick up your ears.
title: Just in time

content:
As the other Snakefang students file off into the corridor on their way to Snakefang House tower, you and Snako quietly sneak away to the side. After two or three turns of the passageway the noise of the other students has faded to nothing.

"Now where?" asks Snako, a tremor of fear and excitement in his voice.

You look around trying to get your bearings. You realise that the school is absolutely huge. There must be hundreds of corridors, archways, passageways and staircases. How will you even find the way to the dungeons?

Just then you notice five spiders walking along the floor, lined up one after the other. What are those disgusting looking creatures up to? you think and start to follow them along the corridor.

They turn left, right, right again, then left before disappearing under a crack in the doorway.

You look up. Above the door is a sign scrawled in thick black letters: DUNGEONS.

"This is it!" you whisper to Snako, afraid to speak too loud in the silence. You reach out to turn the great brass doorknob and open the door. But it doesn't budge, and as you pull on the doorknob the edge of the door glows golden.

"Look!" says Snako to you quietly, "I know what the problem is: the door is enchanted. We'll never open it if we don't know the magic password."

At that moment you hear lots of footsteps coming your way from around a corner. It must be a group of students on their way to their house tower! Before you have time to hide, they turn the corner and spot you.

"Arthur and Snako isn't it? What are you doing there you miserable little sneakers? Get back into line!" To your surprise you are addressed by one of the older Snakefang students. You must have somehow taken a hidden shortcut when following the spiders.
choice_1_text: You slink back into the line and head off into the passageway with the rest of the students. You glance back at the dungeon door as you walk away and narrow your eyes: I'll be back, you think.
title: The dungeon door

content:
Still with the ring on, you creep back around the Hall and take your place next to the other Hedgehog students. Then you remove the ring, put it in your pocket and pretend that you were sitting there all along.

"Where's he gone, that disgusting talking spider?" shouts a boy called Snako from Snakefang house, standing to his feet.

"Yes what's happened to him?"

"Where did he go?"

The insect army, no longer under Azog's powerful enchantment, start milling about like normal insects. Sensing their confusion the students leap to their feet and start squashing insects left right and centre. The arthropod survivors flee into cracks and are gone.

You find Kensley in the crowd.

"Slumblebore couldn't stop them!" she says. "When we got to the dungeon door the insects overpowered him, it was horrible. But where did you come from Arthur? And what has happened to the spider king?"

You shrug your shoulders, give her an enigmatic smile and say nothing.

In not much more than half an hour order is restored: the teachers are cut down and the flattened carcass of the Great Azog  - all that remained after you trod on him - has been scraped off the stage floor.

Slumblebore raises his hands for silence and addresses the students in a slightly shaky voice.

"Students! It appears that my warnings were prescient - there was indeed a terrible doom brewing in the school dungeon. Even now I am not sure how our doom was averted. But be that as it may, everything is now back to normal. So back to your beds, get a good night's rest, and never speak of this again. Particularly not to your parents. Goodnight!"

You take Kensley by the arm and walk companionably back to the Hedgehog House Tower, then up onto the hillside and into your Hogger Hole.

"Goodnight Kensley!" you say.

"Goodnight Arthur!" she replies.

Then you step through the front door of your cosy Hogger Hole and look around you. Everything is exactly as you left it: comfortable varnished chairs, stout walking stick by the door, umbrella in the umbrella stand. You take the magic golden ring out of your pocket, flick it up into the air happily and catch it as it falls.

You let out a large, contented sigh. Yes, everything is back to normal.


CONGRATULATIONS YOU HAVE ACHIEVED THE EVERYTHING IS BACK TO NORMAL ENDING!
title: Epilogue

content:
"I'm not sure I really fit in with my house," you say.

"Not the right house, eh?" repeats Slumblebore. "Well it wouldn't be the first time it has happened. Percy can pigeon hole people a bit too quickly at times - he is getting old now and sometimes I think his heart isn't really in it any more. Despite the fact that we feed him well and he gets to sing a song every year."

"Yes," you say, "I think it just all happened too quickly when I arrived at the school and I didn't really know what it is was going to be _like_ in Snakefang House."

"Hmmm," ponders Slumblebore. "With a bit more time you may come to like it, don't you think? You know that after Percy the Picking Pigeon has chosen your house you can't change it."

"No I'm never going to like it sir," you reply blinking back tears. "I don't even like snakes. I just pretended to, to fit in. I'll just be miserable my entire life."

"Well... in that case there is something I can do. I said that you can't change your house _after_ you have chosen it but luckily I am something of an expert in temporal magic - the magic of time. I can send you back in time to _before_ you have chosen your house and you can choose all over again. How about that Arthur?"

You nod in reply. "Yes thank you sir."

"Well then, just step into this clock over here..." Slumblebore points to a large grandfather clock standing against the wall. The clock face is a little higher than your head and the main body of the clock has a small door, with a space behind that you can squeeze into. 

"I'm going to set the time to after dinner on the first night..."

You can see Slumblebore's feet and flowing robes as he fiddles with the clock face above you. 

"When the clock strikes three you will travel back in time, and if I have got my calculations right, you will also travel sideways in space to arrive in the great hall at just the right time. Remember to come and see me again in my office later on. Or do I mean earlier on? The magic is starting soon now, good luck!"

You can feel a tingling sensation as the magic travelling clock starts to power up. A faint sparkly golden glow feels the space that you are crouched in. You hear the clock strike one, two...
choice_1_text: Here goes, back in time to a new house and a new start at Hogsnorts!
choice_2_text: "Stop, I've changed my mind!" you shout and leap out of the clock. "I don't want to change houses or go back in time!"
title: Time for a change

content:
"I will do it, though I do not know how," you say. 

"My dear Arthur! Students really are amazing creatures. You can learn all that there is to know about their ways in a day and yet after a hundred years they can still surprise you." Slumblebore regards you with twinkling eyes and chuckles.
