"As to the how: first you must deactivate the locking spell on the dungeon door with the magic password: watermelon."

"Watermelon?" you repeat.

"Yes: watermelon. I chose this password because it is my favourite fruit. Then you must descend the staircase that leads down into the very depths of the school. In the past students would be imprisoned in the dungeons for misbehaviour. Now they are mainly used to store broken chairs and Christmas decorations. But we go down there so infrequently there is no telling what evil is brewing in some dark corner."

"I advise you to keep your wand at the ready and your wits sharp Arthur. And remember all the lessons the teachers have taught you. You will be put to the test and I do not know how it will turn out."

"Sir," you ask. "What do you _think_ is down there?"

"Long have I studied this question, seeking knowledge in ancient scrolls and consulting with the wisest of the wise. Not a sausage. All I can say is that in the dead of night when I listen hard at the dungeon door I can sometimes hear a faint scratching noise... like the sound of a million claws far away, scratching and scrabbling at something. Either that or some mice eating a hole in the skirting board."
choice_1_text: Gathering your courage you head out of the office back to the midnight Hogsnorts corridors.
title: What must I do?

content:
Dashing round the corner you raise your wand and yell "Paraguas pronto!"

To your astonishment, from the end of your wand pops out a translucent sparkly golden umbrella.

In a flash it opens up - it is big enough to cover both you and Daniel, which is just as well because in that same moment there is another popping sound and three more splotches of superheated acid from the beetles‚Äô bottoms fly through the air towards you.

Splat splat splat!

The acid hits the magical golden umbrella, protecting you from harm. 

But not the golden umbrella. In a few moments the acid has dissolved it to nothing, just a little bit of umbrella handle is left poking out of the end of your wand. 

The three giant bombardier beetles raise their rear ends at you, and make menacing chittering noises. 

"Retreat!" shouts Daniel, "we're sitting ducks!"

You both turn back and flee, rounding the corner as more blobs of acid hit the wall behind you. 

"That wasn't exactly what I wanted the spell to do..." you explain to Daniel, embarrassed.
choice_1_text: You catch your breath and reassess the situation
title: Taking cover

content:
Looking around you, you can see that you are at the junction of a number of stone corridors.

One passageway has a sign above it saying "Slumblebore's office this way".

Another one appears to lead downwards with a gentle slope.

A spiral staircase climbs up from another doorway. A little sign with an arrow reads: "Your heart's desire's desire."

The new moon shines in from a tall narrow window.

You remember that the corridor to your left goes back to your house tower.

"Where shall we go now Arthur?" asks Daniel.
choice_1_text: "Let's see if we can sneak a look at Slumblebore's office!" you reply. "He must have loads of cool stuff hidden away in there."
choice_2_text: "Let's try and find the dungeon. I want to know what is going on down there that has Slumblebore so worried."
title: Night school
choice_3_text: "I'm feeling tired. Let's go back to the house tower and get some sleep."
choice_4_text: "What do you think 'Your heart's desire's desire' means?" you ask. "Let's go up that staircase and have a look."

content:
"Let's go back to the House Tower," you say to Snako. "I'm tired out, it must be really late now."

The two of you trudge wearily back to the Snakefang House Tower. It is a long way but somehow you remember the path perfectly - perhaps due to some 'homing' magic that all Snakefang's absorb when they first go to the Tower.

Before long you have found your way through the winding pathways and are back next to the lava pool at the centre of Snakefang Tower. The glow of the lava lights everything up an eerie orange colour and Blood Drinker and the other giant snakes are basking next to the pool in the heat. Your nose catches a faint whiff of sulphur as you turn your head to follow the line of the stone staircase winding round the inside of this huge tower to the door of your own personal mini tower.

You feel your spirits lift: could anyone have a better home to come back to than this?

"Night night Arthur," says Snako with a yawn. "See you in the morning."

You both wearily climb the final stone staircase to your towers, unlock the doors with your wands, and enter.

Throwing your robes over the sofa, you have a quick refreshing shower in your bathroom, dry yourself with an enormous fluffy midnight-black towel, climb the spiral staircase to your cosy little bedroom at the top of your tower and drift peacefully off to sleep.
choice_1_text: You wake up in the morning refreshed and happy.
title: Back to the Tower

content:
You choose Offensive Magic with Professor Comicus Jape.

You find the classroom after only a few wrong turns, and take a seat next to Aaron. You frown to see Snako Malboy from Snakefang class sitting down at the desk next to you. He notices you frowning and sneers back.

"Now then children!" Professor Jape calls out at the front of the class. "Now then, now then! It's so lovely to meet you all."

Professor Jape is wearing a black cape with a red velvet lining and has a very pale almost white face. He smiles at the class warmly and gives a little wink.

"Today we are going to learn some offensive magic. Now as you probably know offensive magic can be extremely dangerous. But that's not to say we can't have a bit of a laugh and a giggle as we go along eh? Eh children? Eh?"

Professor Jape makes a loud high pitched giggling noise. Some of the other children laugh back nervously.

"In fact I always like to break the ice with my new children with a joke. Hands up if you want to hear one of my jokes children."
choice_1_text: You put your hand up - you could do with a laugh.
choice_2_text: You keep your hand down - this is a waste of time and you want to learn spells.
title: Professor Jape

content:
"Somnolencia salchicha sabrosa," you cry, waving your wand about energetically.

You feel a tingly sensation waft down your arm and out through your wand. A beautiful shower of golden sparks pours out from the tip and arcs down the corridor raining down onto the three beetles.

Each beetle glows gold for an instant before slowly rolling onto their side and then their backs, six legs waggling gently in the air. 

"Do you think they are ok?" asks Kensley.

"They... they seem to be. That was a sleeping spell. Look you can see their legs are still moving."

They must be dreaming some pleasant beetle dream, perhaps of cantering through a leafy carboniferous glade, as their legs make little wiggles in the air.

"Come on Kensley, let's tip toe past them before they wake up."

You and Kensley carefully walk around the sleeping beetles.

You descend a spiral staircase now and the air is getting dank and stale. It can't be long before you arrive in the dungeon. 

At the bottom of the staircase it is pitch black.

You raise your wand and the tip emits a faint golden light, just enough to see by.

You can't stop yourself emitting an involuntary gibber. 

Revealed by the dim light of your wand you can see the floor and the walls are completely covered in woodlice. Millions upon millions of them cling to the damp stone slabs that make up the corridor. Millions more cover the flagstones, waving their repulsive little antennae. Others have curled up into balls and are rolling around irresponsibly.

Do woodlice even have eyes? You don't know but when you turned on your light they all seemed to turn and look at you. 

"Holy hedgehogs!" says Kensley, a tremor of fear in her voice. "Arthur, what are we going to do? There is no way we can get past so many of them!"

"Try not to panic Kensley" you say in reply. "I have an idea."
choice_1_text: You chant the spell "Fiel fresa fusila fuego."
choice_2_text: You recite the incantation "Amansa at√∫n!"
title: Woodlouse warfare
choice_3_text: You shout out "Dispara dinosaurio demente!"
choice_4_text: You decide that you will just walk forwards, over the woodlice.
choice-5-text: You don't know the first thing about combating woodlice. It's time to retreat, regroup and learn what you can in magic lessons.

content:
Surveying the hordes of woodlice in front of you, you raise your wand up high and cry out in a loud voice: 

"Amansa at√∫n!"

For a moment nothing happens.

Then three glimmering golden bubbles expand into the air in front of you, until they are the size of footballs. Inside each golden bubble is a large golden fish. The fish flap their fins and smile at you happily.

"What is that spell?" Daniel asks you. 

"I'm not entirely sure, I was hoping it would be a whirlwind or lightning strike or something along those lines."

The golden bubbles pop and the three fish flop to the floor with a surprised look on their faces and then disappear with another pop. 

The woodlice look on, unimpressed.
choice_1_text: You wrack your brains for a better idea.
title: A fishy spell

content:
As you shout "Watermelon!" at the top of your voice, you point your wand at the door.

You can feel your arm channel powerful magic. Magical golden lines leap from the tip of the wand. The golden lines strike the door and entwine the handle, the hinges, the iron bands that hold the door together. 

An enchantingly clear note sounds and at the same time the dungeon door swings open.

"You did it Arthur!" cries Snako, and the two of you enter the passageway, wands at the ready. 

Stairs head downwards into the gloom, a gloom alleviated by dim flickering torches, enchanted by magic to burn forever and never go out.
choice_1_text: At the bottom of the stairs you stop and look around you.
title: Pass friend

content:
"Great!" replies Kensley. "Let's start by exploring your hole."

You inspect every room in your Hogger-hole carefully, and find that everything you could possibly need has been stowed away: food, spare clothes, pots and pans, a hoover, cutlery, salt and pepper, spare bin bags, washing up liquid - the place is amazing.

You discover that one of the rooms functions as a little shed with gardening equipment in it, compost and seeds. Kensley is delighted to find a bag of seed potatoes at the back, still in good condition.

Kensley and you immediately set to work in the small garden at the front of your house, clearing more space for the flowers by pulling up brambles, trimming the grass and making a little vegetable plot, where you plant out the potatoes you found. 

Feeling tired you go to your kitchen and make a pot of tea and rummage out some seed cake and a few scones, with pots of strawberry jam and clotted cream. You and Kensley sit on little wooden chairs in the front garden in the sun, and eagerly chomp your way through the delicious food and sip hot tea.

Refreshed you turn to Kensley: "What do you say to a little ramble?"

Both of you stroll along the path among the Hogger-holes in the side of the hill. Most of the students have gone to their lessons but there are a few who have decided to stay behind to weed their gardens or just sit and enjoy the autumn sunshine, and you greet them as you go by. 

"Good morning Brian Banana."

"Pleased to make your acquaintance Rebecca Radishbottom."

"How do you do Betty Appleton?"

Everyone is friendly and happy to see you even though this is your and Kensley's first day as Hoggers.

You stroll down to a river at the bottom of the hill and spend a moment watching the sunlight sparkle on the water. Then you notice some flat pebbles on the riverbank and you take turns skimming them across the river. 

"Four bounces Kensley, that's a record!" you cry in triumph. 

"You liar. That was never four, the last bounce was a sink," she says with a smile.

"It was four bounces, I saw the splashes!"

"Oh yeah, well how about this for a splash!"

With that Kensley gives you a playful but firm push and you topple backwards into the water. 

For a moment you are submerged, and as you scrabble for something to hold onto, your hand touches something. Something small and hard - you close your fist instinctively. When you come up to the surface you realise you are holding a beautiful shiny golden ring. 

As you climb onto the river bank dripping water Kensley announces that it is her birthday. This is a bit unexpected but, making the best of it, you decide that jewellery usually goes down well as a present, and give her the golden ring.

"Happy birthday!" you say. Kensley says nothing in reply and slips the ring into a hidden pocket with a sly look on her face. What odd behaviour! you say to yourself.

Then it's off to the hole to get changed into dry clothes, putting your wet and muddy clothes from the river into the enchanted washing bucket, and reciting the 40 degrees wash incantation.

Then to Kensley's house for dinner where you have a delicious meal in front of a cosy fire. After which you take it in turns to read poetry to each other, followed by thirty minutes of 'Animal Crossing' in the games room.

At last the other Hogger students start returning from their lessons to Hoggerton (this is what you are calling this collection of Hogger Holes) and one of the shouts out to you as they go past: "Dinner time Arthur, Kensley - in the Great Hall!"
choice_1_text: Even though you have already eaten one dinner tonight, it would be a shame to turn down free food. You head to the Great Hall.
choice_2_text: You couldn't eat another thing. Besides it's time for bed and apart from that peculiar incident with the ring, it has been the best day ever.
title: Bunking off

title: What must I do?

content:
Everyone on Hedgehog table is very pleased to have you in their house, and smiles at you as you take your seat. 

"Welcome to Hedgehog House Arthur!" says one boy, who looks like he is in the oldest year. "You dodged a curse by joining Hedgehog House that's for sure. We look after each other and stay out of trouble here I can tell you. Hoggers up!" he suddenly shouts.

The children around the table spontaneously break into the Hedgehog House chant, reciting loudly as they stand up and sit down in together:

"Hoggers up, hoggers down, hoggers hoggers stand your ground."

You let out a sigh of contentment. This is the place for me alright, you think, proud to call yourself a Hogger.

You are even happier when - the rest of the House Sorting complete - Slumblebore magically conjures up an incredible feast for dinner.

From out of thin air materializes platters of roast beef and boiled sprouts, Yorkshire pudding and mashed turnips, shepherds pie and boiled broccoli, toad in the hole and boiled potatoes, bubble and squeak and boiled carrots, apple crumble with strawberry ice cream, and spotted dick drowning in custard.

"Boiled potatoes, my favourite!" Kensley Potato, a first year who was also chosen for Ravenclaw House, licks her lips.

You and Kensley get chatting over dinner about the different ways of cooking potatoes and before long you are firm friends.

In a rite of initiation all the first years crack open the eggs they received from Percy the Picking Pigeon and guzzle the contents raw.

Then you eat more than you have ever eaten before, enjoying yourself immensely. You wonder if Slumblebore is somehow making the food magically disappear after it enters your stomach, in a similar way to how he made the food appear on the table. But finally you realise you can't cram anything more into your belly, and let out a huge belch.

"Children!" Slumblebore stands, his beard streaked with mashed turnips and the odd boiled potato. He raises his hands for silence. "Children! Now we have eaten our fill it is time for bed. Prefects lead the students to the House towers. And remember: the dungeons are off limits this term. We don't know what's down there, and neither do we want to."

The children rise to their feet, clutching their distended tummies, and prepare to leave the hall. 

You turn to Kensley Potato and say:
choice_1_text: "It's been a long day, let's go to the House Tower"
choice_2_text: Shall we go and find out where the dungeon is?
title: The first feast

content:
Slumblebore's office is easy to find, you just follow the signs pointing the way. When you reach it you see that the door is slightly ajar - and there is a light still on inside. Perhaps Slumblebore has gone to bed and forgotten to turn the light out.

You motion Daniel to wait outside and he nods. "Be careful!" he whispers.

You push on the half open door and immediately hear a voice:

"Come in Arthur." It's Slumblebore - you've been rumbled!

"Don't worry," Slumblebore says as if reading your thoughts. "I have been waiting for you to come. I wanted to talk with you."

You walk into Slumblebore's office and look around you. Every inch of space has been used. Leather bound books on bookshelves line the walls. Paintings with ornate golden frames are hung all around, and ancient Hogsnorts headteachers stare down at you, blinking and sniffing. From the ceiling hang silver cages containing magical golden birds, tiny jewelled monkeys no bigger than your thumb and baby dragons curled up and sleeping. On the floor pentagrams have been marked out in yellow chalk and you almost trip over a live weasel dressed in a little red waistcoat that must be a Slumblebore's pet.

Slumblebore himself is sitting behind a massive wooden desk, piled high with manuscripts, scrolls, steaming goblets, plates of watermelon, little bowls of nuts and weasel droppings.

"Care for a raisin?" Slumblebore offers, brushing some weasel droppings onto the floor and proffering you a bowl.

"Err no, thank you," you reply, not entirely convinced that the bowl is 100% raisins.

"Arthur, I'm glad you have come. There is something very serious for us to discuss, which concerns the safety of the entire school. I need your help. But first tell me, how are you settling into the school? Do you feel happy in your new house?"
choice_1_text: Yes it is amazing, you reply. "But what did you want to talk to me about?"
choice_2_text: "Well, I do like the school," you say. "But I'm not sure that I am in the right house. I don't feel like I really belong there."
title: Slumblebore's office
choice_3_text: You reach out to stroke the weasel, a very curious looking creature in his little red waistcoat.

content:
"Die beetles, die!" you cry, running towards the three giant bombardier beetles. 

In your battle rage you forget all about magic and your wand, you just want to reach the beetles and grapple them with your bare hands, mano a beetlo.

"Yaaaah!" you cry, closing the distance fast...

...but not fast enough. The three beetles swiftly raise up their bottoms, and shoot out three streams of superheated acid, accompanied by three loud popping sounds.

One stream misses your head by inches, another strikes the wall beside you, the third the floor in front. 

"Hahahaha, you missed me, you little..."

But you never get the chance to tell them exactly what type of little things they are because at that moment your foot slips on the pool of acid on the floor and slides out from underneath you. You fly through the air very briefly before slamming into the floor, bumping your head hard enough to knock you out cold.
choice_1_text: You remain unconscious for an indeterminate length of time
title: Battle rage

content:
Professor Eric Knid's classroom is on the ground floor, in a wing of Hogsnorts castle that sticks out a little from the main building. The windows look onto vegetable gardens on one side and some overgrown brambles on the other.

You walk into the class with Daniel and sit down.

Professor Knid stands at the front patiently while the children settle. His long arms and legs poke out of his wizard's gown. A strange shimmery cloak dangles from his shoulders. Dressed all in black he looks rather like an overgrown spider.

When there is silence he raises his hands. His odd looking cloak flutters around him while he speaks:

"Today you will learn about the care of magical creatures.

"But before we do that let me take this opportunity to remind you of Slumblebore's warning at the house sorting dinner." Professor Knid looks out at the class with a piercing gaze and it appears to you that his eyes are focused directly on you.

"No-one must go into the dungeons this term. There is something mysterious and very probably dangerous down there this term, and no-one is allowed to interrupt. Is that clear?"

Nods all round from the class. You exchange raised eyebrows with Daniel. What could be going on down there? And why was Professor Knid staring straight at you?

"Right!" Knid claps his hands."Can anyone tell me the most common type of magical creature?"

"Basilisks?" shouts out one boy.

"Boggart!" shouts a girl at the back. 

"Banshee!" shouts someone else. 

"These are all good answers. But not correct. The most common type of magical creature is the insect, or, more generally: the arthropod. Spiders, snails, flies, ants, beetles, woodlice these are all infinitely more common than the boggart. And many of them have been enchanted by a magician or witch at some point in the past making them effectively immortal until trodden on. 

"For example, look closely at my cloak children." Eric Knid walks up and down the class so the children can see better.

You realise that the professor's cloak is not merely shimmering, it is _moving_. It seems to be made up of lots of tiny moving _things_. Then you realise what they are and your eyes widen in hideous fascination.

Eric Knid's cloak is made up of thousands upon thousands of flies, each fly grasping the flies next to it with their tiny hairy legs. As they flutter their wings or move their black and iridescent green bodies, the cloak appears to undulate as if in a breeze. 

To you and the rest of the class it seems revolting, but Professor Knid is oblivious.

"Until you look closely my cloak is just an ordinary magician's cape. But it is actually made up of thousands of enchanted and specially trained flies. And each one can fly off at my command to do my bidding - to deliver a message perhaps, or sit on someone's dinner, or to distract a powerful wizard in the act of casting a spell.

"Yes the insect world is a vast and overlooked wonder and in this lesson I am going to teach you about a tiny portion of it.

"But before we learn any magic, does anyone doubt me that the arthropods - the insects - are the true marvels of the animal world?"

Professor Knid looks round expectantly, his eyebrows raised.
choice_1_text: You don't like insects that much. You raise your hand to ask what makes them better than other animals.
choice_2_text: You don't say anything. Clearly Professor Knid had got a bugbear about insects and he is just itching to waste the whole lesson talking about them. You would rather learn some magic.
title: Professor Eric Knid

content:
Making sure no-one is following you, you and Daniel tip-toe out of the Hogsnorts Dining Hall.

It is pitch black outside but the corridors are lit by enchanted glow globes that give off a golden light.

After a while it is totally silent - everyone else has gone back to their house towers to sleep. The only noise you can hear is the padding of your feet on the flagstones, and the occasional screech of a barn owl from an open window.
choice_1_text: After a while you and Daniel reach the centre of the school. You look around.
title: Night time explorations

content:
You and Snako decide to investigate the nearest stone staircase. From the bottom all you can see is that it winds up to some shadowy and little visited part of the school. 

At the top of the stone stairs, you encounter a passageway lined with suits of armour. The empty helmets are turned in your direction and twist to follow you and Snako as you walk past. Even though you know they are just ordinary suits of enchanted magical armour the effect is still rather creepy.

At the end of the corridor there is a single door which swings open on silent hinges at your touch.

The room inside is small, dark and bare - but not quite empty.

Next to one wall there is a mirror, with the words above it 'Look at me if you dare, you will see your soul laid bare'.

Opposite, against another wall there's _another_ mirror. Above this one it says 'Stare at me and you will see, what you want to come to be.'

Snako relaxes. "I know what these are! They're mirrors of desire. They show you what you most want in your whole life, maybe even something you didn't even realise. My mother's got one of those in the downstairs toilet."

"That's amazing!" you breathe, and step up in front of one of the mirrors nervously.

You look at your reflection in the mirror and see...

...a taller, more handsome version of yourself. Your chest is pinned with many shiny medals and on your shoulders are an enormous pair of golden tasselled epaullettes. You are wearing an expensive pair of sunglasses and you can just make out a huge crowd of people behind you who seem to be cheering for you. Your reflection grins at you and you are momentarily blinded. Every tooth is capped in pure gold.

"Wow look at me, I look like some kind of super cool dictator!"

Then you catch the reflection of the mirror behind you in the mirror in front of you - the reflection of the reflection.

In _that_ reflection you are quietly reading a book sitting on a comfortable leather chair, calmly stroking a handsome white cat. 

"That's funny," you say. "The reflection of my reflection in the mirror behind me doesn't look so cool at all..."

Then it dawns on you.

That gold medal champion version of yourself doesn't _want_ all that power and attention. He's bored of it all - _I_ would be bored of it all. What you are seeing is the dictator version of you's most earnest desire - which is for a quiet life, reading a book, stroking a cat.

You angle your head to catch more reflections of reflections and see the images of yourself curve away into infinity. 

With each reflection's reflection the cool version of yourself is just that little bit less cool and the quiet version of yourself becomes a little bit less quiet. Far into the depths of the mirrors you can just make out an Arthur just like yourself, waving back at you.

You shake your head, confused, and tell Snako what you saw.

"That's it!" he says. "Don't you see? The person you really want to be, when you get right down to it, is yourself."
choice_1_text: Pondering the profound implications of this idea, you and Snako leave the room of the mirrors, walk back along the corridor past the suits of armour, down the winding stone staircase to end up back where you started, at the centre of the school
title: Mirror mirror on the walls

content:
You enter the passageway sloping downwards and after many twists and turns in the passageway you are hopelessly lost.

You notice a little spider running around a corner ahead of you. Curiously it then comes back round the corner, looks at you and waits, then lifts up a spindly leg and points.

"Arthur" says Aaron, "I think that spider wants us to follow him."

With no better idea of where to go you follow the spider as it turns this way then that and are delighted to finally arrive at what must surely be the entrance to the dungeon.

"Yes, Aaron, we've found it!" you whisper fiercely, giving Aaron an excited whack on the shoulder.

A huge wooden door, banded with silver inlaid iron, stands within a stone archway. Either side of the door two antique sets of armour are positioned upright as if on guard. 

The spider you were following scurries through the keyhole of the door and disappears. You wonder where he is off to.

Above the door there is a sign written in some archaic font, which reads: "DUNGEON".

You try the doorknob but it doesn't budge. 

"There's a magical enchantment of locking on the door remember!" says Aaron. "We will need to cast a counter spell if we are to get through."

As you lift up your wand, you rack your brains to try to think of a spell that might work.
choice_1_text: "Openus Sesamus!" you cry
choice_2_text: "Door lock undone, unlock door done!" you say
title: The dungeon door
choice_3_text: "Ziggidy zaggady zock unlock!" you chant
choice_4_text: "Watermelon!" you shout
choice-5-text: It's no use, you can't remember any unlocking spells, you will have to go back to your dormitory to sleep and try to learn one tomorrow.

content:
"Yes there is something I need to talk to you about Arthur, something very important," says Slumblebore. 

"Ever since the end of the last school term I have sensed an evil presence in the school. An evil presence that is growing stronger by the day. All that I have been able to determine is that it is coming from the school dungeons. But _what_ it is and _where_ exactly it is down there I do not know. Whatever it is, is beyond my power."

Slumblebore looks at you directly, his bushy eyebrows waggling. 

"This is where you come in Arthur. I need you to investigate what is going on in the dungeon. And deal with it."

"You want me to go to the dungeon!" you ask, amazed. "But you said at the school dinner that the dungeon was forbidden and no children were to go anywhere near! It's not allowed!"

"Yes but Arthur don't you see? I can't just go around encouraging all the children to go down into the dungeons. There would be a stampede! And imagine if anything happened to them? Their parents would take Hogsnorts School to court, the fines could be crippling! No far better if you could just handle this quietly. And don't tell anyone that I told you to go down there."

"But I don't know any magic at all, hardly!" you exclaim, "I've only just started magic school!"

"I agree you should learn one or two spells before you venture down. Pay attention to your teachers! What they teach you could save your life."

"But why me sir? Why not ask one of the older children to do it? Why don't _you_ do it?"

"There is one more thing I haven't told you Arthur. In the summer holidays I discovered an ancient prophecy concerning the school. It was written on a scroll that was so old that as soon as I touched it it turned to dust. It said:

::: text-poem
'_When darkness falls across your school. 
And evil threatens to rise and rule,  
When monsters lurk around school ground. 
The boy called Arthur must be found._'
:::

"Your coming has been foretold. If the prophecy is correct, only you can save us."

"And if you do this thing Arthur," Slumblebore adds, "I will personally award one million points for Hedgehog House."
choice_1_text: What must I do? you ask, with a determined look in your eye.
choice_2_text: I'm s-s-sorry, you stammer, "I just can't do it sir, I'm just a child!" As you leave the office Slumblebore calls after you: "I'll be here waiting for you Arthur, when you find your courage."
title: The prophecy

content:
Professor Eric Knid's classroom is on the ground floor, in a wing of Hogsnorts castle that sticks out a little from the main building. The windows look onto vegetable gardens on one side and some overgrown brambles on the other.

You walk into the class with Kensley and sit down. For this lesson Hedgehog House first years have combined with Snakefang House first years. Snako Malboy - a first year Fanger - sits down on your other side and sneers at you unpleasantly. 

Professor Knid stands at the front patiently while the children settle. His long arms and legs poke out of his wizard's gown. A strange shimmery cloak dangles from his shoulders. Dressed all in black he looks rather like an overgrown spider.

When there is silence he raises his hands. His odd looking cloak flutters around him while he speaks:

"Today you will learn about the care of magical creatures.

"But before we do that let me take this opportunity to remind you of Slumblebore's warning at the house sorting dinner." Professor Knid looks out at the class with a piercing gaze and it appears to you that his eyes are focused directly on you.

"No-one must go into the dungeons this term. There is something mysterious and very probably dangerous down there this term, and no-one is allowed to interrupt. Is that clear?"

Nods all round from the class. You exchange raised eyebrows with Kensley. What could be going on down there? And why was Professor Knid staring straight at you?

"Right!" Knid claps his hands."Can anyone tell me the most common type of magical creature?"

"Boggles?" shouts out one boy.

"Mere-cats!" shouts a girl at the back. 

"Wyrms!" shouts someone else. 

"These are all good answers. But not correct, although that last one was a good try. The most common type of magical creature is the insect, or, more generally: the arthropod. Spiders, snails, flies, ants, beetles, woodlice, these are all infinitely more common than the Boggle. And many of them have been enchanted by a magician or witch at some point in the past making them effectively immortal until trodden on. 

"For example, look closely at my cloak children." Eric Knid walks up and down the class so the children can see better.

You realise that the professor's cloak is not merely shimmering, it is _moving_. It seems to be made up of lots of tiny moving _things_. Then you realise what they are and your eyes widen in hideous fascination.

Eric Knid's cloak is made up of thousands upon thousands of flies, each fly grasping the flies next to it with their tiny hairy legs. As they flutter their wings or move their black and iridescent green bodies, the cloak appears to undulate as if in a breeze. 

To you and the rest of the class it seems revolting, but Professor Knid is oblivious.

"Until you look closely my cloak is just an ordinary magician's cape. But it is actually made up of thousands of enchanted and specially trained flies. And each one can fly off at my command to do my bidding - to deliver a message perhaps, or sit on someone's dinner and do a little poo, or - distract a powerful wizard in the act of casting a spell.

"Yes the insect world is a vast and overlooked wonder and in this lesson I am going to teach you about a tiny portion of it.

"But before we learn any magic, does anyone doubt me that the arthropods - the insects - are the true marvels of the animal world?"

Professor Knid looks round expectantly, his eyebrows raised.
choice_1_text: You don't like insects that much. You raise your hand to ask what makes them better than other animals.
choice_2_text: You don't say anything. Clearly Professor Knid had got a bugbear about insects and he is just itching to waste the whole lesson talking about them. You would rather learn some magic.
title: Professor Eric Knid

content:
Perched on the shoulder of Professor Knid you see an average sized spider gazing at you thoughtfully through his compound eyes. 

"But, but... he's just a little spider!"

"Have some respect!" snaps the Prof. "The Great Azog is of average size for a spider."

"Size isn't everything, young Arthur," says King Azog the spider on the Prof's shoulder. "As you yourself - a first year - well know."

"But Oh Great Azog," you ask "What's so special about me?"

"Your wand shows that you are special Arthur. The core of your wand has a strand of silk from my bottom. Do you know how many other wands contain my silk? None whatsoever. Yours is the only one. You and the wand were made for each other.

"You and your wand therefore have an unmatched power over all spiders in the world, as I do. But with your wand you are also bonded to me. Our fates are entwined, threaded together. Together we could achieve anything.

"That's why I brought you here: to join me.

"You didn't bring me here!" you protest. "I came here by myself, I _chose_ to come here."

"You may think you did but every step of the way I was guiding your steps, bringing you closer.

"Who guided you to the disabled toilet in Leeds Railway station, which led you to Hogsnorts? I was the spider that showed you the way.

"Who gave you the courage to face Percy the Picking Pigeon by biting you on the bum?" I was that spider.

"Who showed you the way to the dungeon door? I was that spider too."

"But what do you want from me?" you implore. "You say I should join you but what are you asking me to do?"

"The time will soon come" says the Great Azog "For you to make your choice. This time one that really matters. But first _I_ have a decision to make."

With that the Great Spider King of average size, who had been talking to you from the shoulder of Professor Knid all this time, takes a few quick steps sideways over to the Professor's neck and, without warning, bites down with his fangs.

Instantly Professor Knid collapses to a heap on the dungeon floor and starts snoring.
choice_1_text: What did you do that for? you cry.
title: The great Azog

content:
You raise your hand and ask "Please sir. Aren't lions better than insects? They're much bigger and stronger."

"Spoken like a true Lionpaw student! Lions! Pshaw. But Lionpaws are not known for their intelligence. No boy lions are _not_ better than insects.

"Firstly: lions can't fly but insects can. Insects have been flying for over 350 million years! And we are always so impressed by the birds. Look at me, look at my feathers, I'm a bird! But insects have been flying for twice as long as birds - birds only evolved 150 million years ago. Pathetic.

"Secondly: a lion may look strong but even an ant is stronger. An ant can carry up to fifty times its own body weight. A lion would struggle to give another lion a piggy back. An ant is more than fifty times stronger than a lion! 

"Thirdly: how many lions are there in the world? Not many I can tell you. Or how many mammals even? So all the lions, humans, cows, horses, mice and dogs put together?

Mammals make up only 0.4% of all animal species.

Insects species make up 70% of all animal species, and if we include all arthropods that's over 80%. That means for every one mammal species (like a lion) there are _170 insect species_.

"No, it is clear to me, as it should now be clear to you, that lions are pitiful, almost inconsequential creatures compared to insects and arthropods."

"But sir," interrupts Aaron, "insects _are_ a bit disgusting..."

"Oh the prejudice! They may also find you disgusting young man but does that make you so? There will come a day - and maybe sooner than you think - when everyone will appreciate the beauty of an insect, when people don't shudder when I brush past them with my cloak. Yes you will appreciate those 'disgusting' insects soon enough my boy."

Professor Jape paused and pinched the bridge of his nose with two fingers. "Class dismissed. Your homework is to write an essay with the title 'What I love most about insects and arthropods'. Two thousand words minimum."
choice_1_text: A collective groan rises from the children. You pack your bag and shuffle out of the classroom with the rest of them - hopefully the next lesson won't be such a disaster!
title: Knid's insects

content:
You and Aaron start pushing at the spider web with your hands.

It is amazingly strong and also _sticky_. When you push a strand it becomes harder and harder to unstick your hands.

"Arthur", cries Aaron, "I'm stuck!"

You turn to the side and see that somehow Aaron has got himself totally tangled up in the web - he is hanging upside down with spider webs curled round his ankles and his hair brushing the floor.

"Don't worry Aaron, I'll get you out!" you reply but as you try to move over towards Aaron you feel thick ropes of spider web curl around your legs and lift you up into the air. In an instant you are as helpless as Aaron.

You feel your panic rising as you struggle. Who is going to help you now? No-one even knows that you are here except perhaps Slumblebore.

"Aaargh! Look Arthur - spiders! Millions of spiders!"

Aaron is right. Crawling out of the cracks of the walls, floor and ceiling is a host of spiders. They scurry along the webs heading for you and Aaron. In a sudden insight you realise that these spiders have made the webs themselves, working as a one enormous team to add strand after strand of spider silk until they had created these thick cobweb ropes. So many spiders working as one! What could they not achieve together?

Then all thoughts flee from your mind as the wave of spiders reach you. They stop inches away.

One lone spider - no bigger than the rest - scuttles out of the pack, delicately steps onto your robes then up to your neck. You see a flash of tiny fangs then you fade into unconsciousness.
choice_1_text: As the sleeping poison takes effect your last thought is - did that spider wink just at me?
title: The dark web

content:
You find yourself face to face with a trio of bombardier beetles, who seem to be guarding the way. 

"Look how big they are!" says Snako. "I bet they are not friendly."

One of them makes an angry chittering sound. Even though you don't speak beetle you are pretty sure this beetle doesn't like you. 

The three beetles turn around in the corridor to face away from you. 

"Look they're running away, the cowards!" shouts Snako letting out a crazy half-laugh.

Suddenly there is a loud popping sound and a steam of superheated liquid shoots out of the beetles' bottoms. 

"Duck!" you cry, and you and Snako throw yourself to one side. The liquid misses you by inches. The stone flagstone bubbles and fizzes where the liquid struck it.

You both pick yourself up off the floor and scramble back round the corner for safety.

"That was too close," you say. "We need to find a way to destroy those beasts, or at least get them out of the way."

You think hard, there must be a spell that you can use. Some spell that kills them or puts them out of action for a while.

After a moment, with a fierce glint in your eye, you decide. You leap out from your hiding place, your wand at the ready.
choice_1_text: Yelling "Tweetle beetle bottle battle!"
choice_2_text: Shouting "Paraguas pronto!"
title: Beetle battle
choice_3_text: Screaming "Die beetles, die."
choice_4_text: Crying "Somnolencia salchicha sabrosa!"
choice-5-text: This is all getting a bit hairy, you decide that the best course of action will be to retreat and come back tomorrow, having learnt some anti-beetle spells.

content:
Making sure no-one is following you, you and Snako sneak out of the Hogsnorts Dining Hall.

It is pitch black outside but the corridors are lit by enchanted glow globes that give off a golden light.

After a while it is totally silent - everyone else has gone back to their house towers to sleep. The only noise you can hear is the padding of your feet on the flagstones, and the occasional screech of a barn owl from an open window.
choice_1_text: After a while you and Snako reach the centre of the school. You look around.
title: Night time explorations

content:
You and Kensley decide to investigate the nearest stone staircase. From the bottom all you can see is that it winds up to some shadowy and little visited part of the school. 

At the top of the stone stairs, you encounter a passageway lined with suits of armour. The empty helmets are turned in your direction and twist to follow you and Kensley as you walk past. Even though you know they are just ordinary suits of enchanted magical armour you can't help a little gibber of fear.

At the end of the corridor there is a single door which swings open on silent hinges at your touch.

The room inside is small, dark and bare - but not quite empty.

Next to one wall there is a mirror, with the words above it 'Look at me if you dare, you will see your soul laid bare'.

Opposite, against another wall there's _another_ mirror. Above this one it says 'Stare at me and you will see, what you want to come to be.'

Kensley relaxes. "I know what these are! They're mirrors of desire. They show you what you most want in your whole life, maybe even something you didn't even realise. My granny's got one in the bathroom."

"I'm not sure I want to look..." you say, but your curiosity compels you to step up in front of one of the mirrors.

You look at your reflection in the mirror and see...

...a beaming, chubbier and slightly older version of yourself. You are wearing a lovely pair of green wellington boots and a fetching brown tweed waistcoat. In one hand you hold a bunch of the largest carrots you have ever seen and in the other a trophy on which you can just make out the words 'Gardener of the Year'.

"Kensley look, I'm chief gardener. And look at the size of those carrots!"

Then you catch the reflection of the mirror behind you in the mirror in front of you - the reflection of the reflection.

In _that_ reflection you are calmly sitting at a table, wearing worn out clothes, and pushing seeds one at a time into little pots filled with compost. 

"That's funny," you say. "The reflection of my reflection in the mirror behind me doesn't look like an award winning gardener at all..."

Then it dawns on you.

That Gardner of the Year version of yourself doesn't _want_ all that fame and attention. He's tired of it - _I_ would be tired of it. What you are seeing is the top gardener version of you's most earnest desire - which is for a quiet life, doing what he really loves: growing vegetables.

You angle your head to catch more reflections of reflections and see the images of yourself curve away into infinity. 

With each reflection's reflection the chief gardener version of yourself is just that little bit less successful, with slightly shorter carrots, and the quiet version of yourself becomes a little bit less shabby. Far into the depths of the mirrors you can just make out an Arthur just like yourself, waving back at you.

You shake your head, confused, and tell Kensley what you saw.

"That's it!" she says. "That must be it! The person you really want to be, when you get right down to it, is yourself."
choice_1_text: Pondering the profound implications of this idea, you and Snako leave the room of the mirrors, walk back along the corridor past the suits of armour, down the winding stone staircase to end up back where you started, at the centre of the school.
title: Mirror mirror on the walls

content:
"Openus Sesamus!" you cry, flourishing your wand.

The door starts to shine with a magical golden glow.

You almost can't believe it but it looks like you have guessed the password correctly.
choice_1_text: "It's working!" Aaron cries out.
title: It's working!

content:
Making sure no-one is following you, you and Kensley tip-toe out of the Hogsnorts Dining Hall.

It is pitch black outside but the corridors are lit by enchanted glow globes that give off a golden light.

After a while it is totally, eerily, silent - everyone else has gone back to their house towers to sleep. The only noise you can hear is the padding of your feet on the flagstones, and the occasional screech of a barn owl from an open window.
choice_1_text: After a while you and Kensley reach the centre of the school. You look around.
title: Night time explorations

content:
With a groan you open your eyes.

Looking around you you appear to be in the Hogsnorts School hospital. You see Aaron lying next to you on an identical bed, also groaning. Various medical instruments hang on the walls: stethoscopes, ear trumpets, syringes, magnifying glasses.

How did I get here? you wonder. Then it comes back to you and you shudder: the dungeon. 

Something bad is definitely going on down there. Now even more than before you realise that you _have_ to stop whatever it is that it is happening. It is up to you - and for next time you know at least one choice that you should not make again...

"Hello Arther, Aaron. I see you have returned to the conscious realm." Madame Blavatsky, the Professor of Defence Against Dark Magic walks into the room. 

"Wssrrflbittit?" you mumble.

"Yes you had quite a shock back there I'm sure. When Slumblebore found you, you were both completely unconscious. But don't worry you will make a full recovery - the antiodarkotics I gave you will flush all the bad magic out shortly."

"Thank you" you manage to say.

"But the most important thing is that you get some rest. I'm going to cast a sleeping spell on you now, timed so that you will wake up tomorrow morning at 7am. When you are sleeping soundly I will teleport you to your own en-suite bedrooms in your House Tower."

As she chants the magic words "_somnolencia salchicha sabrosa_" you try to speak but you can't stop yourself drifting away.

What is in the dungeon? you want to ask. Your lips form the word "Wha...?"...
choice_1_text: Then you drift off into a deep healing sleep.
title: A speedy recovery

content:
"Good morning Brian Banana!"

"Good morning Arthur!"

"Good morning Kensley Potato. Kensley! Kensley? Now where has she disappeared to...?

"Good morning Rebecca Radishbottom!"

"Good morning Arthur!"

"Good morning Azog the Great!"

"Good morning young Arthur!"

You sit down on the bench next to Azog, outside the insects' Hogger Hole, and enjoy the feeling of the mid morning sun on your face. 

It's been a year since you led the insect horde out of the school dungeon to their new abode, a year of hard work, a year of peace. 

You still remember those first days as if it were yesterday. Kensley was delighted to find you alive and well and even more delighted when you gave her back the ring she dropped.

The other Hedgehog House students were initially uneasy about an insect army moving in next door, but you passionately defended them, explaining that this was the only way to end generations of suffering - of insect bites and wasp stings versus crushed ants and swatted flies. 

Acceptance from the Hoggers only came in full measure when the insects started helping out with the vegetable gardens, keeping the plants free from pests and nourishing them with their own tiny droppings. If a snail gave into temptation and nibbled on a lettuce leaf he was soon restrained by his fellow creatures.

The Hoggers were thrilled and the arthropods were here to stay. 

"How are the little ones Azog?" you ask kindly. 

"Coming along very well, thank you Arthur. There's a new batch of ten thousand ants hatching this week, and fifteen thousand fly larvae will be pupating shortly."

"That's wonderful news," you reply. You are particularly happy about the flies as they are the eyes and ears of the colony, buzzing off to investigate the doings of neighbouring shires.

"And how about your carrots Arthur?"

You reach into your basket and proudly pull out a bunch of carrots of monstrous size, each as big as a squidditch stick. 

"I will win first prize at the fair for sure!" you reply. "I couldn't be happier - and I couldn't do it without the insects! Their manure is first rate."

"The droppings of the arthropods - not to be sniffed at. But it's the least we can do to say thank you. From the first moment I saw you I knew you were the special one. Thank you Arthur. Thank you for leading us here. We have peace in our time because of you, and it is small recompense to provide you with the ordure of the arthropods."

CONGRATULATIONS, YOU HAVE ACHIEVED THE LIVING IN HARMONY WITH INSECTS ENDING
title: Epilogue

content:
It takes you just an instant to decide. 

Whipping out your wand you cry "Fiel fresa fusila fuego!" and flames shoot out, bathing the dungeon in flickering light. No way are you going to let these disgusting insects take over - you are going to fight back and destroy them, starting with Azog!

Azog is too nimble to be caught so easily though and leaps out of the way.

"You will regret your choice Arthur," screams the spider king in outrage. "Insects, attack!"

From out of cracks in the walls, ceiling and floor crawl millions upon millions of arthropods: beetles, woodlice, ants, millipedes, earwigs, spiders in a great stream heading straight for you.

This time you don't hesitate. If you stay you will be surrounded and overwhelmed. You turn and run. 

Your heart pounding, you run back out of the dungeon up towards the school. You have a plan.

When you reach the enchanted door that leads down into the dungeon you dash through and slam it shut. You can hear the enchanted locking mechanism clicking shut.

There's only one way for the insects to get past the door now - through the keyhole. You turn and wait, your wand at the ready.

As soon as you see the first hairy little leg poking out of the keyhole you use your wand as a flamethrower shouting "fiel fresa fusila fuego" again and again until your voice is hoarse.

The air is full of the harsh high pitched cries of dying arthropods and the sizzle of roasting chitin. But still the insects come, propelled onwards by the Great Azog's iron will.

You are getting tired now, your arm is sore from being held up so long and you can feel your reserves of magical energy running out. You cannot hold out much longer.

For a moment the magical fire from your wand flickers and dies.

Then three things happen simultaneously: 

One: Azog, sensing his chance, launches himself through the keyhole aiming straight for your face. 

Two: Snako and Slumblebore run round the corner to see you battling the numberless insect foe on your own.

Three: your faltering spell was a trick. You have enough magical power for one last spell...

"Fiel fresa fusila fuego!" you scream pointing your wand at Azog as he flies through the air towards you.

Then...

Azog, leaping through the air fangs at the ready, is unable to change direction. Just as your wand arm comes _up_ he reaches the tip of the wand, only to be blasted backwards by a concentrated jet of magical fire. Even the great Azog cannot withstand an attack at such close range. He hits the wall next to the dungeon door, his legs still on fire and body a smoking ruin.

The last words of Azog the Great are "Arthur... you have roasted me...". Then a final puff and Azog is no more.

With Azog a gonner the rest of the arthropod hordes lose all cohesion. When Slumblebore cautiously opens the door to the dungeon they are fleeing in all directions, and will trouble the school no more. Slumblebore lets off a few more blasts of fire to encourage them on their way.

"You did it Arthur!" cries Snako. "You saved the school - the evil has gone!"

You stand still and listen carefully. Snako is right. You cannot sense the insects any longer. The dungeons have been cleansed.

"Well done indeed Arthur," and Slumblebore, turning back to you. "I had a feeling that you were the special one. Without you I fear we would have been overrun by insects by now."

"It was Eric Knid," you say to Slumblebore. "It was Professor Knid who summoned the insect army, with Azog the spider king. He is down in the dungeon now unconscious. Azog bit him."

"Eric did you say? Well I'm not surprised. He always struck me as a bit of an odd fish. Nevermind we will pick him up in the morning and I shall give him an official reprimand. And if he does it again I will have no choice but to put him on a performance improvement plan."

"But you Arthur, what else can I give _you_ but my most heartfelt thanks." You can't suppress a broad grin. You did it! You defeated Azog and his insect army single handed!

Slumbelbore continues: "You truly are a hero Arthur, a hero of Hogsnorts School."
choice_1_text: The next day...
title: School hero

content:
Along with most of the other children you keep your hands down.

"You don't want to hear my jokes? Well I never!" Professor Jape looks genuinely hurt for a moment, but quickly recovers his composure.

"Perhaps you will be laughing on the other side of your face by the end of this lesson." Jape gives another high pitched giggle and you all shift on your seats uneasily. 

"Maybe," he continues, "you will enjoy this one. I need a volunteer!"

No one volunteers so Jape scans the classroom. He points at Aaron.

"You! Come forward."

Aaron shuffles forward to the front of the class. 

Without any warning Professor Jape whips out his wand, points it at Aaron and yells: "_Vamos varita vencer vistosamente!_"

A golden light extrudes out of the tip of Jape's wand. The light looks like a solid sparkly golden beam and extends for one metre then stops. Jape swings his wand around and you realise that he has created a magical golden light sword! As the golden beam swipes through the air it makes satisfying swishing zoom noises.

"En guard!" snaps Jape to Aaron with a gleam in his eye before suddenly launching into a frenzied attack, swiping left and right with his light sword. In a flash he has covered the 5 metres to Aaron and he holds the light sword directly at Aaron's throat.

"Now you will die." Jape says simply.

There is dead silence in the class. Everyone is holding their breath.

Then, almost in exact unison, everyone screams and runs out of the door, except Aaron who is rooted to the spot in fear, and you because you don't want to abandon your friend.

Professor Jape lowers the light sword and gives a high pitched giggle.

"I were just joking, didn't you know that?" he said to the fleeing children. "It were just a joke!" he shouted louder at their fleeing backs.

Professor Jape sighs and says to you and Aaron: "They can't take a joke, can they? Well lessons over now I suppose. But remember: _Vamos varita vencer vistosamente_ that's a good one that is!"

You and Aaron nod and swallow, and without saying another word, flee out of the classroom.
choice_1_text: You dash back to the dining hall to find another lesson, hoping the next teacher won't be quite so bonkers.
title: Jape's spell

"Now you will die." Jape says simply.

There is dead silence in the class. Everyone is holding their breath.

Then, almost in exact unison, everyone screams and runs out of the door, except Snako who is rooted to the spot in fear, and you partly because you don't want to abandon your friend, and partly because you have a morbid curiosity to see what will happen next.

Professor Jape lowers the light sword and gives a high pitched giggle.

"I were just joking, didn't you know that?" he said to the fleeing children. "It were just a joke!" he shouted louder at their fleeing backs.

Professor Jape sighs and says to you and Snako: "They can't take a joke, can they? Well lessons over now I suppose. But remember: _Vamos varita vencer vistosamente_ that's a good one that is!"

You and Snako nod and swallow, and without saying another word, flee out of the classroom.
choice_1_text: You dash back to the dining hall to find another lesson, hoping the next teacher won't be quite so bonkers.
title: Jape's spell
